Overpopulation can be defined as a situation where the total number of the existing human population exceeds the actual carrying capacity. Of all the environmental problems our planet is facing today, overpopulation is the one that sometimes slips from the radar. Overpopulation places a great demand on resources and land, which may be the reason for widespread environmental issues in addition to impacting global economies and standards of living.
Poverty is to be believed as the major cause of overpopulation. High mortality rate and lack of educational resources, leads to high birth rates, resulting in a large population.
If overpopulation grows, this effect is said to be so widespread that the United Nations has predicted that the 48 poorest countries of the world contribute to the largest population growth. They estimate that the combined population of these countries is expected to be 1.7 billion in 2050 from 850 million in 2010.

The effects of the overpopulation are quite severe. One of these is the lack of natural resources. Earth has the capacity to only produce a limited amount of food and water, falling short of current needs of the people which are increasing day by day.

Rapid population growth makes the choice between high consumption and investment needed to bring more consumption in the future more scarce. Economic development depends on investment. Therefore, rapid population growth repels the investment needed for higher future consumption.

With a rapidly growing population, the adjustment becomes difficult to manage with economic and social change. Urbanization in UDC creates problems like housing, electricity, water, transport etc. In addition, the growing population is at risk of permanent environmental damage through urbanization in some rural areas.

The rapidly growing population transforms the economy into mass unemployment and low employment. As the population increases, the ratio of workers to the total population increases. The result is that with an increase in the labour force, unemployment and low employment increases. Rapid increment of the population reduces savings and investment.

Domestic consumption of exportable goods also increases with rapid population growth. As a result, there is a decline in the exportable surplus. On the other hand just to meet the demand of the rapidly growing population, more food and other consumer goods are needed so that demand can be fulfilled.

What is I learned in AP Human geography is really helpful because as though some of the information is wrong like the Demographic Transition (DMT) and the possibility of stage 5 (for country's like Japan Greece Germany Ect) existing. Correctly More Developed Countries (MDCs) have a more developed economy people have access to birth control while women have access to education and can have lives without having kids. In Less Developed Countries (LDCs) they don't have that. More people are engaged in Subsistence agriculture and doing stuff to survive and feed there family not focused on other things. Whereas in MDCs less than 2% engage in Commercial Agriculture and other people are engaged in specialized jobs in a commercial economy. It's much different. And to develop a country is a lot of time, effort, money, and determination from the people and it does not always work out. And in an effort to develop a country they get loans from world banks and sometimes this can end up exploiting a country economy. Our population will eventually level off. The medical revolution and the 2 & 3 Agriculture Revolutions  will diffuse to the LDCs. This video sums this up pretty well and is amazingly simple and easy to understand. If you were to look at it from a more complex angle factor including, Cultural Customs & Beliefs, Agriculture, Migration, Political Geography, and the Development of a country all plays a roll as well. If you have the chance to take AP Human Geography do it is an awesome class. This was an amazing video the people who made it did an amazing job I mean no offense of my previous comments.

This is a myth stated by Thomas Malthus in 1798 when he sat down and did a little math (let's just say he wasn't great at math) then came to the conclusion that the world would be out of food by 1890 and blamed reduced mortality rates and said the only answer was to kill the poor so the rich may continue to survive. Of course that didn't happen but that lie has been carried ever since 1798 with the only change being the year it is expected to happen. Then again in 1968 by Paul R. Ehrlich of Stanford university who claimed that unchecked human reproduction had overwhelmed the Earth and would destroy 1/5th of humanity by the end of the 1970's and the planet would end soon after. Again this didn't happen. This constant fear tactic did achieve one thing however. Huge donations to organizations like the UN and WEF.  Because of that this lie has been carried on in varying degrees without a single person using a little common sense to question the previous thousands of years of humanity.

Well made video. However, as happens so often the ecological context is missing. Humans focus on social and economic aspects forgetting that we are dependent on the ecosystem. We’ve been in overshoot for 50 years now, and it's been getting worse and worse. Overshoot means that we are depleting the earth's resources faster than they can regenerate - which will eventually lead to collapse. Today we're 7.9 billion people on the planet. The current overshoot is 1.7 which translates into a carrying capacity of 4.7 billion people at current consumption rate. If consumption rates are desired to increase to move people out of poverty that number gets lower. If perhaps other species that don't directly serve humans are granted some space that number goes down further. - In any case the outcome is detrimental if passengers are added to an overloaded ship, even if fewer are added than before.

The population in 1800 (before industrialisation) was as follows:

Europe: 150 million
Africa: 90 million
Asia: 700 million

Theoretically, when we reach level 4, we should expect the population to increase about fivefold since 1800 and then remain roughly constant or even decrease. This is the current population distribution:

Europe: 750 million
Africa: 1,300 million
Asia: 4,600 million

This is the UN's projection for 2100:

Europe: 630 million
Africa: 4,300 million
Asia: 4,900 million

Europe hits the factor of 5 quite well, Asia has overshot the expectation of 3,500 million because of India, Pakistan, the Philippines and the Middle East. Asia has 1,400 million too many people. But that is "only" a 30% carryover. Africa, on the other hand, should only be home to 450 million. According to UN predictions, however, 4,300 million people will be living there in 2100. That is a carry-over of 950%. That means that the population there has not only increased fivefold, but even fiftyfold. You are right that the population grows in phases, but nevertheless the population growth in Africa cannot be described as a "natural rule", which we Europeans have also experienced. That is not the case. If this were the case, there would have to be 7,500 million people living in Europe alone today.

One aspect this video doesn't seem to consider is that with better medicine and advanced societies, life expectancy has skyrocketed too.
Bangladesh, since it was used as an example, went from a life expectancy of 47 years in 1971 to 60 years.
That means you get three generations alive at the same time, instead of two.

If you check the data, you can see it went from 65 mil people in 1971, to 105 mil people in 1991.
Birth rate went down by 25% (less people), death rate went down by 50% (more people), so that's +25%. Add that 3rd generation and you end up with the roughly 60% increase you see between 71 and 91.

The models presented don't take into account the amount of stupid people that are saved every day by today's society (don't stick your kids into the washing machine, don't eat detergents etc.) and those people don't really have a good track record when it comes to keeping kids at a minimum.
Add to this the fact that nowadays those who focus on careers and have only one child or none at all end up supporting families of retards with 10+ kids and the theory of stupid people overpopulating the planet is not so far fetched.

Kurzgesagt is awesome and I often use his videos in my Biology or EnviSci classes I teach.  However this video is a bit one-sided.  Progress has come at a severe cost... which ultimately hurts us humans likely more than we gained.  Our current gains are at the expense of the future. The use of resources increases dramatically with advancing societies. More wood, more metals, more energy etc.  This damages the Biosphere and contributes much more to Biodiversity loss and Climate change than when humans are lesser in number and less advanced.  And this is likely to reverse our course (in both advancement, well-being, and numbers) in our childrens or grandchildrens generations.

"According to the U.N. Population Database, the world’s population in 2010 will be 6,908,688,000. The landmass of Texas is 268,820 sq mi (7,494,271,488,000 sq ft).
So, divide 7,494,271,488,000 sq ft by 6,908,688,000 people, and you get 1084.76 sq ft/person. That’s approximately a 33′ x 33′ plot of land for every person on the planet, enough space for a town house.
Given an average four person family, every family would have a 66′ x 66′ plot of land, which would comfortably provide a single family home and yard — and all of them fit on a landmass the size of Texas. Most of human history is little more than peoples' adaptation to new technology and overpopulation.  In the 1890s, Europe put chlorine in the drinking water, fewer children died, and a generation later, they had World War 1; a generation after that, Hitler needed "living room" for the German people, and they had World War II.    In the United States, the marriage rate has dropped below that of the Great Depression.  Automation is taking so many jobs and threatening to take so many more that young people are scared to get married because very few can support a family.  I suspect that the low birth rate in stage 4 is more likely a reaction to feared poverty as human workers are out-competed by machines rather than some esoteric concern for the rest of humanity. So it will be ignored and avoided until it becomes plainly obvious that the population level is totally unsustainable and at that point those with the most power will do what they think needs done to ensure their survival and continued quality of life even if its "distasteful". There are in fact 8 stages of the demographic transition.

1. Birth rates and death rates are very high

In many undeveloped countries, they tend to see high birth rates, but also high death rates due to bad living conditions, so the population hardly grows

2. Birth rates are high, but death rates drop

Eventually, as countries tackle those problems, the death rates will fall, causing the population to rise dramatically.

3. Birth rates drop and death rates drop

After sometime, countries will have been more developed, and having more babies is unnecessary and economically impossible; and therefore, birth rates begin to drop, which means that the population will begin to slow.

4. Birth rates and death rates are low

Eventually, countries will see birth rates and death rates being very low, and the population is hardly growing at all.

5. Birth rates drop below death rates, even though they are both very low

In countries like Japan, Italy, Greece, Germany, and the Balkan and Slavic countries have birth rates that are actually lower than the death rates, despite them being so low. In those cases, those countries see a negative growth in their population, meaning that their population is actually shrinking.

6. Birth rates and death rates reach minimum possible lows

At some point during a country's population decline, the birth rates and death rates are at their minimum possible lows, and the rate of decline slows down.

7. Birth rates only rise; whereas death rates do not

Eventually, the population will level out again due to birth rates solely rising.

8. Birth rates rise above death rates, but net growth rate is very low

In countries like Germany and Austria, their projections show that they are going to rise again, but at a much slower rate. In this case, birth rates have risen above death rates, but only slightly above death rates, meaning that the population is rising again, but it is rising at a much slower rate than before.
So this mean that the world population will peak at 10.875 billion people in 2100, and then decline to 8 billion by 2300, and then increase very slowly after that.

The bigger question is will we be able to sustain a population of 10 billion living with first world country conditions? We're already relying on the economic efficiency of fossil fuels to maintain our standard of living, and our planet can't survive humanity the rest of the world speeding through their own industrial revolutions. To achieve worldwide carbon neutrality by international cooperation AND supply the whole world with a first world country standard of living BEFORE we run into freshwater shortages, sea level problems, or farmland destruction will be incredibly difficult for humanity to overcome.

However, we have overcome challenges like these before, and we will do so again.It's not a matter of IF we will come out of this, but in what shape we will be. Will only powerful countries survive while billions starve? Will superpowers annihilate each other over dwindling resources? Will society break down as people struggle to care for their own? Or, will we unify together to overcome this issue as one species?

Yes, but the problem is that the demographic transition is too irregular in the world, leading to ethnic conflict and cultural decline. while European countries reached it a century ago, Asia and South America are now getting there with greater problems (cities much more overwhelmed than their European counterparts at the same time of transition), Africa is still in phase two for a century and probably will be for at least another 30 years or more. To make a comparison for every European in 1900 today there are 1.9 Europeans, for every African in 1900 today there are 10 Africans and in the future perhaps from 25 to 40. Furthermore many countries for religious or cultural reasons sabotage any family planning plan . The world until the industrial revolution had its demographic balance which saw Asia have 60% of the world population, Europe 15%, Africa 10-15% and America 10%. The industrial revolution had increased the European population to 25-33% of the world population, which allowed Europe (thanks to the simultaneous presence of a large population and the best technology) to dominate the world. Today Europe at 5-7% of the world population is heading towards an even greater decline, on the contrary Africa which today has reached 17% (from the minimum of 7% in 1900) will reach 25-40%. Does this mean that Europe will exist only as a geographical extension, moreover how will it be able to compete economically, politically or culturally with an Afria that accounts for 40% of the world's population? So the biggest problem of the modern demographic transition is that it is too irregular creating continuous global imbalances and causing entire peoples and cultures to decline as well as favoring the extreme right. Furthermore, European countries have entered the 5th phase, that is birth rates lower than 2.1 which lead countries to lose population and to grow old. Countries like France can withstand fertility rates below 2.1, because they have a lot of immigration but above all because their rate is very close and is 1.9 making each generation 5% smaller than the next. But countries like Italy or Ukraine cannot solve the demographic drop with immigration, because they have too low fertility rates (1.2-1.3) which lead them to an intergenerational drop of 40%. This means that the new generation will have to support a generation 140% bigger. Except for Africa which has a fertility rate of 4.4 children, the rest of the world has a fertility rate of 2 children not 2.5 (which are given by African fertility). The fundamental problem is African fertility.
Sì, ma il problema è che la transizione demografica è troppo irregolare nel mondo, portando al conflitto etnico e al declino culturale. mentre i paesi europei l'hanno raggiunta un secolo fa, l'Asia e il Sud America stanno arrivando lì con maggiori problemi (città molto più sopraffatte delle loro controparti europee allo stesso tempo della transizione), l'Africa è ancora nella fase due da un secolo e probabilmente lo sarà per almeno altri 30 anni o più. Per fare un paragone per ogni europeo nel 1900 oggi ci sono 1,9 europei, per ogni africano nel 1900 oggi ci sono 10 africani e in futuro forse dai 25 ai 40. Inoltre molti paesi per motivi religiosi o culturali sabotano qualsiasi piano di pianificazione familiare. Il mondo fino alla rivoluzione industriale ha avuto il suo equilibrio demografico che ha visto l'Asia avere il 60% della popolazione mondiale, l'Europa il 15%, l'Africa il 10-15% e l'America il 10%. La rivoluzione industriale aveva aumentato la popolazione europea al 25-33% della popolazione mondiale, il che ha permesso all'Europa (grazie alla presenza simultanea di una grande popolazione e alla migliore tecnologia) di dominare il mondo. Oggi l'Europa al 5-7% della popolazione mondiale si sta dirigendo verso un declino ancora maggiore, al contrario l'Africa che oggi ha raggiunto il 17% (dal minimo del 7% nel 1900) raggiungerà il 25-40%. Ciò significa che l'Europa esisterà solo come estensione geografica, inoltre come potrà competere economicamente, politicamente o culturalmente con un'Africa che rappresenta il 40% della popolazione mondiale? Quindi il problema più grande della moderna transizione demografica è che è troppo irregolare creando continui squilibri globali e causando il declino di intere popolazioni e culture oltre a favorire l'estrema destra. Inoltre, i paesi europei sono entrati nella quinta fase, ovvero tassi di natalità inferiori a 2,1 che portano i paesi a perdere popolazione e invecchiare. Paesi come la Francia possono resistere a tassi di fertilità inferiori a 2,1, perché hanno molta immigrazione ma soprattutto perché il loro tasso è molto vicino ed è 1,9, rendendo ogni generazione più piccola del 5% rispetto alla successiva. Ma paesi come l'Italia o l'Ucraina non possono risolvere il calo demografico con l'immigrazione, perché hanno tassi di fertilità troppo bassi (1,2-1,3) che li portano a un calo intergenerazionale del 40%. Ciò significa che la nuova generazione dovrà supportare una generazione più grande del 140%. Ad eccezione dell'Africa che ha un tasso di fertilità di 4,4 bambini, il resto del mondo ha un tasso di fertilità di 2 bambini non di 2,5 (che sono dati dalla fertilità africana). Il problema fondamentale è la fertilità africana.

"The percentage of people living in extreme poverty has never been as low as today". - While this statement may be true, consider the fact that the world's richest 1% has more than twice as much wealth as 6.9 billion people.

I love Kurzgesagt but I have a few criticisms of this video.

The most prominent one is I believe that this video neglects the holistic global poverty situation, and fails to consider the existence of gross disparities among the global wealthiest and poorest.

Secondly, this video analyzes population growth and human development from an ethnocentric perspective i.e. from the perspective of the developed West. It echoes sentiments of the ethnocentric Modernisation Theory.

I hope you'll considering doing a video about global inequality if you already have not.

The fascinating part lies in the fact that there is a correlation between wealth and birth rates. The wealthier a country is, the lower its birth rate becomes over the years, as it transitions. Wealth also breeds education, which encompasses many aspects. Incidentally, the best birth control is life expenses. A wealthy country, means a very expensive and high standard of living, which acts as the most effective birth control mechanism. How expensive is living in a certain city or country, remains quite relative to that one city or country. Even in countries with subsidized utilities, no taxes, and very high income like Saudi Arabia, birth rates have went down from 7.3 in 1970 to 2.2 in 2019,( The Replacement Level is 2.1) which means that it will continue to go down further. Which proves the fact that egotistical altruism is the best form of altruism. As elevating the living conditions, and economic perspectives of other places, will be beneficial for all, as the first by-product of such an occurrence will be the sharp decline in breeding, as people shift their priorities elsewhere. The question that I ask, do we have enough time to make these changes viable for other places that continue to dwell in abject poverty? Considering how automation is next door, and that climate change is accelerating?

comment_text:
I'm extremely sceptical of the information in this video.

For a start, many aspects, such as opportunities to procreate, are diminishing significantly - as are marriage rates.

Careerism seems to have become a higher priority for women in more recent times, suggesting that they are more likely to be focused on their work tasks, rather than bringing up children.

Secondly, toxins have become more prevalent in our air, food and water supplies, leading to possible infertility.

Also, abortions (as a form of birth control) are prolific, as it has been "legal"ised.

Promiscuous behaviour reinforces the likelihood of this even further.

Pharmaceutical products contain agents which may compromise fertility in both women AND men.

Having many sexual partners means that any commitment to marriage lessens over time, and age of consent legislation imposes artificial restriction on procreating with the most biologically fertile group.

There are other aspects which are concerned with legal (not lawful) matters, that centre around impositions of "registering" the berth (birth) of an infant.

In other words, "statistics" could be used to supposedly back up figures of birth rates.

Whereas before these acts came into being, how exactly were these numbers established??

An argument, could say that they were just invented afterwards...

Whilst disease would certainly have been more prevalent at that time, however, people would have had some reliance, on their immune systems (notice the number of allergies people now suffer from?)

Not only that, but antiquated societal structures permitted females to marry and have children much younger at that time - meaning that a parent was more likely to successfully give birth while they had the chance.

Now, as for the appearance of an ever increasing number of people in day to day life, it could be the case, that there may be a deliberate effort to "herd" people into population centres, such as NYC, London, Tokyo etc., as well as [effectively] streamline routines (ie work from 9-5, all travelling at 8am and 5.30pm) just to reinforce this idea of overpopulation (as well as other nefarious reasons).

One apparently overt statistics (rather extreme), suggests that the birth rate in South Korea, is currently 0.75 children per couple - less than HALF the "sustainable" rate.

Japan wouldn't surprise me by having similar statistics, and, almost inevitably, the west will most probably follow.

Whilst this video seemed quick to point out that a lot of infants died not long after childbirth, it didn't say *why*.they died.

Whilst I haven't researched this myself, an educated guess might point towards deficiencies in their immune systems (possibly because of poor health/treatment of the mother).

In parts if the African subcontinent (especially the east) people are now severely deficient in food, water, and medicine, meaning that sustenance is becoming ever more difficult - an epidemic of AIDS really seems to seal their fate, I'm sorry to say.

When China had it's one child policy, that significantly contributed to inhibiting population growth.

Lastly, financial restriction deters many from giving birth - that - and social divisiveness caused by growing mistrust between the sexes.

I've been telling people this for years:  just take a plane trip somewhere -- anywhere -- and pick a window seat.  Spend some time looking out at the Earth below.  What do you see?  People?  No. You see land, water, farms, roads, etc.  You my see EVIDENCE of people -- cars on the road with one or perhaps two people in each one.  You see houses, with perhaps two or three people inside each.  But you do not see crowds of people standing shoulder to shoulder, crowded for space and starving.  Even looking down at big cities you see big buildings and rivers and roads, bridges, and cars -- again, evidence of people, but not masses of bodies fighting for survival.  Anyone who talks of overpopulation or population control (Chinese communists for example) are simply nut-cases with no facts or powers of observation.

The main premise of this video is flawed. It states that world population growth will slow as more underdeveloped countries transition to become developed countries. The problem is that each person in a developed country has much more of an impact on the Earth’s environment than each person in an underdeveloped or developing country. People in developed countries live much longer, consume much more of the Earth’s resources, pollute more, add more to climate change and contribute more to the displacement / extinction of other species.  As an example, in North America each person on average uses 100 times more water than a person in Africa. So even if the world population does level off, that increasingly affluent population will still have an ever increasing impact on the Earth’s environment. The size of the Human population will still be a problem.

We have to pay for the mistakes of our predecessors and the older generations for not having done ANYTHING to improve the planet for us and for not having done ANYTHING to resolve the climate crisis or overpopulation of humans. They only thought of themselves their entire lives to buy land and property. They have left the major problems of overpopulation and global warming to the younger generations to resolve. As younger generations grow up into adulthood, they are faced with ridiculous house prices and costs of living. Older generations have their cushy retirements and pensions paid for through the taxes of the struggling younger generations who have no more notches on their belt to tighten as these selfish people snapped up all the property while being oblivious to the two of the biggest problems the world faces - global warming and over-infestation of humans. The fact of the matter is, DON'T HAVE CHILDREN if you can't resolve these global problems or provide safe long-term shelter, food, financial support and decent education for your child.

This video leaves out the CRITICAL FACT that when the first societies industrialized and populations boomed the planet had enough resources to support them (unfortunately industrialized countries obtained those resources via imperialism, which laid the bedrock for world wars and remains the underlying cause of many major political conflicts today). NOW, WE HAVE ALREADY EXPLOITED EARTH PAST THE BREAKING POINT. There simply isn't anything left to sustain the ongoing, absurdly HUGE population boom with enough time to balance back out, nor the ability (or even the sociopolitical will) to overcome the massive planetary damage we've already inflicted. Scientists aren't looking so desperately at space exploration and colonization (more imperialism) because humanity is the curious, intrepid space explorer depicted in the media. Scientists have verified the proverbial "writing on the wall"; they've tried to tell us that EARTH WILL RESET AND IT WILL NOT BE FUN NOR PRETTY FOR MOST/ALL OF CURRENT LIFE ON EARTH if we don't mitigate the situation ourselves, but, of course, we can't (or don't want to) believe it. Instead, when the global conversation gets tough and/or scary, we buy into the "snake oil" salesman's fear/anger tactics and hope that he'll "make us great again", or that it makes sense to divide us (the EU) for self-interest, rather than uniting and sticking together to have the ability to achieve large-scale solutions. I understand that this video endeavors to soften the blow, and give us hope. But, I don't believe it's realistic nor productive. Realistically, we need to be scared enough to take whatever real action is still available to us.

Darwin's theory of Evolution and his research suggest that when food supply is plentiful it support a trend of larger versions of an . animal species (like birds)... and when food supply is poor or low that it support a trend of smaller versions of an animal species with every successive generation... a comedy science fiction movie called downsizing (2017) takes this as its basic premise as a way to comment on how consumerism affects people .
human  population have been curbed  mostly by war, famine,  and disease....and by a lesser extent by poverty and crime.

The argument to keep the poor poor and focus on just saving the elite ruling class in Europe when it faced over population == Malthusian Trap.

USA and European urban population grown was not supported by the industrial revolution but due to turn of the 20th century (cir 1870-1900) Urban public health signaled by massive support for clean potable water, water sewage treatment, and storm water management.

In China and in India , the population growth before the industrial revolution was made possible by agricultural productivity improvements

China's one child per family policy was triggered on a UN report urging that China control its population to prevent over population... India -whichhas a larger population than China - ignored the UN report has fear mongering ....which was published in the early 1970s....

Dr John Calhoun of John Hopkins University did sociological behavior experiments on how rats and mice dealt with overpopulation ...Cr Calhoun called the point where rats and mice exhibited anti social behavior due to the stresses
of over population as reaching a Behaviorial sink the result and data are not in question but the interpretation of the results have been and still are debated to this day.

Uhh.. I'm not really buying it. I'm not trying to be some conspiracist or anything, but think about this. For the population even stay STABLE, every couple must have AT LEAST two children, and that is just assuming that every single human finds a mate (and that the male to female ratio is completely even for all purposes of this thought experiment). That also means for the population to double, every couple of the WORLD (still assuming that everybody has found a match) on average must have four children each. So with that being said, how many people do you know have four children? Think about it people, I'm not going to tell anybody what to think, but shouldn't we at least consider the possibility that the global population might be inaccurate? Even if every couple didn't have two children, many people die without even having children at all, how could the global population possibly even be growing? The people that choose to have children literally need to have enough to compensate for all the others that do not, so for every three people that choose not to have children, the couples that DO CHOOSE to have children need to have six babies on average to make up for the others for the population to even remain STABLE. Though it might seem obvious, i'll point out that if every couple only had one child, the potential population would diminish by 50%. Yes, we can throw life expectancy into account, but then we still have to consider how exactly the population was able to "double" with life expectancy down that much. 7.4 billion is a LARGE number, and when you venture around the world, it's kinda interesting to wonder where the fuck all these people are.

It seems pretty clear why the first nations to progress through the demographic transition took several decades longer than nations do today. Part of that transition for the first nations involved advancing science and technology that was necessary for some of the steps in the transition to take place. For example, mortality rates won't decrease until you produce the medicines and treatments necessary to prevent deaths. So nations that are today developing, already have the science and technology to develop, so it won't take them nearly as long to progress through the demographic transition.

Normally I love these videos and find a lot of valuable info in them. This one is well-done too, but I find myself disagreeing strongly with the notion that "more people is better." Sure, it's better if everyone lives well, and sure, more people doesn't mean permanent exponential growth; but the problem with "more people" is that we can't sustain the level of consumption we're dealing with right now - more people will only make that worse. When the UN is projecting a total collapse of fish stocks in Asia by 2048, among other alarming predictions, one has to wonder - should we really have more people when we can't manage the populations we're dealing with currently?
I don't understand humanity's fascination and obsession with growth: more stuff, more things, more, more, more. Why can't we just take what we have and make it the best it can be? Why does there always have to be more?

The overpopulation discussion fails to include resources like individuality and the competitive struggle to stand out. Keeping humans alive isnt the problem but quality of life is much more challenging in modern days. People are even more unhappy now than in decades past despite technological advances. This isnt because modern people are shallow, far from it as when people move past caloric struggles they move onto more abstract realms (like self actualization.)

As material wealth increases social competition and intensity increases exponentially with population. The human psyche evolved to live in small groups and is stressed in the more nuanced but cluttered and dense living conditions. This makes people and social relationships quickly replaceable and less meaningful to the people in those societies. The thresholds to meet the raised social expectations increases the difficulty for standing out. Any quick look at Instagram culture shows a the runaway game of social one-upsmanship that reflects the consequences of population growth.

The biggest and more likely outcome of increased population isnt apocalyptic but more dull with a spiritual emergency (suicides will only increase.) This isnt just a problem of material resource management (like food/water) because we can actually succeed in doing that.

This video essentially presents the argument that population growth is not, nor will not be a problem that we need to concern ourselves with ever in the future because the tendency is that population growth is naturally decreasing (as evident in developed countries) and extreme poverty is decreasing as well, even as the population continues to grow, so therefore the population will likely eventually stabilize with no more increase whatsoever and whatever extreme poverty remains will not be attributable to the overall size of the population. Well frankly, I believe this conclusion to be largely inaccurate because of the following:
1. The argument presented that extreme poverty is decreasing has flaws, and as resources become more and more limited per capita, the decreasing trend may not hold true forever. According to the graphical evidence used in the video about poverty, the graph showed that essentially 100% of the population of the world lived in extreme poverty back in 1815. That means that whomever created the graph was considering "extreme poverty" to be some unexplained value judgement based on today's standards (like an average life expectancy being greater than 40 years). Whatever the value judgement is, extreme poverty should not only be based on a value judgement based on today's standards, but also on the standards of the time. For example, I would argue that in 1815, 99% of the population was not living in extreme poverty, This might lead to the perception that the percent of the population living in extreme poverty at any given time should actually be a fixed value (at something like 6% of the population), but fixing a poverty rate at a certain value also leads to an incomplete analysis because if someday 99% of the population was enslaved, and forced to work hard labor, then a fixed percent (such as 6%) would not accurately reflect how much of the world is living in poverty. The reality is that even though we tend to recognize extreme poverty when we see it, extreme poverty can not easily be defined nor measured because we all have different perspectives of what it is. When analyzing the issues of an increasing population, I would argue that it is not wise to base any conclusions about the health of our planet on some vague concept of the "extreme poverty" of humans, but rather on the overall ability of all of the rest of the planets species to survive on the planet in a natural environment void of human interaction.
2. It is very unlikely that the overall rate of population growth will ever reach a value of 0% or less unless political actions are taken because as growth rates begin to approach 0%, certain individuals and organizations get worried about the economy and begin to campaign for increasing the size of the population citing historical economic data as a reference, and people begin having more babies again. The problem is that as the population increases, and resources become more and more limited per capita, proportional population and economic predictions based on historical data will suddenly be irrelevant when a limitation of resources eventually forces an unprecedented population bubble to burst. By that time, yes the size of the population might begin to stabilize, but not without some drastic economical and environmental setback that will probably come as a drastic reduction in the overall Quality Of Life for all humans and species together. Alternatively, if governments could collectively step in early enough, they might be able to slow the population growth rate to a small enough percent where the human species could figure out how to evolve without affecting the natural environments of all the rest of the species, and we might be able to maintain a high Quality of Life, but I am very skeptical that we will be able to get our act together for that. I suspect we will continue to grow until we have utilized about 99% of the world's land area for human capitalistic purposes and only after a huge number of the earth's species go extinct, and only after a majority of the population begins to struggle to be able to earn enough to have a decent Quality of Life by the standards of the day will the population begin to stabilize. I also suspect that at that point the average Quality of Life for someone will be very different than it is today; yes, more technology and human created entertainment may exist, but there will be fewer interactions with true nature as it will be much less abundant and accessible. Other things may become less accessible too, like meats, as they will become increasingly expensive. In the end, true nature is what we will have lost, and that will be the greatest shame that our ignorant logic (as is evident by this video) will have brought us.

With exception of the content of the narrative, I would like to apologize for my strong criticism of this video to the editors and producers of this film however, as I thought the graphics and editing were decent. Thanks for making me think...

Good vid! Two points of critique though:
1) the industrial revolution did the exact opposite for women. Prior to it, women and men worked side by side in domestic prodcution, usually sharing the burden. This gave women relative power to as they helped provide. With the industrial revolution, the workplace and the home became seperated, with the 'traditional' division between women manning the home and men working. The result was that now the husband provided and women 'merely' looked after the house and kids (in richer homes, sometimes not even that).

2) This video does not take into account that while population growth is slowing down, they are still growing overall and the strain on resources is already far too much. In 2015 the news went out that by May, we had already used up all the earths natural production for that year and were running on what we had stockpiled (which fortunately was a lot). At to that, that developed countries use much more resources on average, so the developing of other nations, while morally good, is not good news for the resource outlook.

Keep in mind that the social structure of the society can differ even across development levels.

For instance, the freedom of women and how they moved from the homes to the workplace has been noted to be an important variable in explaining the reduction of population growth.

However, in for instance Islam, women experience a very low comparative rate of freedom. Contrary to popular belief, this is not limited to merely developing countries, but also to modern islamic countries, and has played a central role in explaining Islam's large demographic growth. Islam is fast becoming the world's major religion, and it is notable in that the growth of the religion is mainly due; not to religious converts; but rather due to sheer rates of birth of its followers.

The social structure and policy adopted by the given society is therefore important in predicting the society's growth rate as well, and therefore the threat of overpopulation will be determined by what social and cultural forces we allow to influence our path forward.

Note: We are technically already overpopulated as we have already passed the threshold of what's sustainable for our planet, because if the current world population was to assume a US standard of living the planet would not be able to sustain the resource cost. Therefore we are in a race against time to expand our resource harvest beyond our immediate planet.

This only works if societies ACTUALLY progress, and don't regress into higher birth rates among those in poverty.

There are a myriad of reasons why this could occur, be they ideological, or religious. Things like the religious sentiment that "good folk must be fruitful, and multiply", could easily come into vogue, and double the population (at any time), in the span of less than a single generation.

While I don't disagree that things certainly seem to follow the pattern explained in the video, this is actually the first edition of this pattern, and we REALLY don't know how it ends up. What we can say, for sure, is that we're getting close to capacity, with respect to our current agricultural technology, and resources. Furthermore, the potential for a catastrophic population spike, is looming overhead, and all it takes is a new generation's "baby boom", with abortion, and birth controls being constantly politically debated, we can't say with ANY certainty what the future actually holds. All we really have are optimistic, and pessimistic opinions, and frankly, its the optimism that's more dangerous, as it has a tendency to ignore potential hazards, like extreme political, religious, or just plain ideological polarization that sides with higher birth rates (for whatever reason).

We simply can't rule out the chance of it occurring, and educate people about the potential pitfalls of high population, and consumption. Because, if the should happen to forget, or ignore those dangers, for any reason, it takes less than a decade for the population to potentially double.

That is why I don't really care for people simply asserting that we should simply ignore the issue, because it'll work itself out. The whole point is that we need educated people to make more responsible choices, in order to avoid the issues of over population. And furthermore, I don't think we're approaching over population, I think we're already there, and I also think we'll be damn lucky to keep this planet inhabitable, from here. Most people agree (on all sides of this issue) that humanity is over consuming, but this issue oddly splits people around the issue of there simply being to many consumers. Because, lets not forget, that in America, while birth rates are gradually declining, consumption rates are off the freaking charts, and increasing per consumer. If the rest of the world were consume like that, right now, there isn't enough supply.

I'm curious to see why this video didn't take into account the concept of an ageing population.
Now, maybe this is me talking out of my arse because I'm hardly well-educated in the subject, but don't demographics show that as people are living longer, that same increase elderly population requires care and support, economically and otherwise, but because we're having fewer children there's not enough people to support that elderly population? I remember reading something a few years ago about France offering incentives for people to have children because of this problem.

Whilst that isn't overpopulation per se and isn't overly relevant to this video, I think it's still something very relevant to consider about the population explosion - that overpopulation itself isn't dangerous because of so many people needing to battle for resources or what have you, but because a country's infrastructure can't comfortably support the amount of elderly it will have to due to our birth rate declining. Sure, we'll pull through it just fine, it's not going to end the world or anything, but worth taking a look at to see if it can be avoided.

The problem is that it is unproven that this will spread everywhere or be permanent.  For any grow rate of A*B^N + C, the constant portion will soon become irrelevant and the exponential portion will dominate the result.   If ONE nation out of the entire doesn't 'advance' in a way which ends rapid exponential population growth, the world will still have exponential population growth.  Alternately, there is no guarantee that the social trends which result in lower birth rates are permanent.  It could be that in 50 years there will be new social trends we cannot currently predict that would encourage larger families.  Again, if only a small % of the world's population continues to grow exponentially, and even if that exponential growth is only in "fits and spurts", the world population will ultimately still be growing exponentially.

What about WHEN we will reach that 0 growth rate?

this is very optimistic. yes prosperity tends to stabilize population growth, but for this to be the solution assumes global prosperity can be achieved in the first place. this requires huge additional sources of energy and resources, can they be made available? it requires greatly expanded agricultural output, can it be achieved, and maintained? what about global political stability, does not that affect prospects for achieving global prosperity? how about the ecological effects of trying to get all that energy, all those resources, all that agriculture online? the global population is certainly going to rise a long way, whether global prosperity is achieved or not- what happens if another world war inconveniently breaks out in the meantime? what happens if the earth's "carrying capacity" is unfortunately reduced precipitously because of some untoward development in the global climate, greatly and negatively affecting agriculture, worldwide? none of this can be taken safely for granted. what I do think is certain, though, is that the human race is deeply divided, worldwide, in all kinds of ways, and that the growth of population we already know is going to happen, is going to put a tremendous load on the abilities of these divided people, to maintain those populations, without suffering famines or other catastrophes, and that's even if nothing goes wrong. I have nothing against optimism, I'm all for it, but I'm also a fan of realism

There's a lot wrong with this video. First, population growth will come to an end, but it won't be the demographic transition that stops it. The world will run out of cheap energy in the form of fossil fuels. Then all those people whose food support was made possible by the Green Revolution (i.e., gasoline or diesel powered tractors) will die by starvation, war, and disease.

Second, the reason that the world can support as many people as it already does is the result of technical activities that are beyond the intellect of most people. The countries in which the sufficiently mentally gifted people live are being invaded by people from lower-average-IQ countries. The result will be a reduction in the number of people who can create new technology and a reduction in the number of people who can maintain existing technology.

This is another kind of "transition" that a country can go though: racial downgrading. A more capable race is replaced by a less capable race, after which the country is unable to contribute the technical innovation that it once could, or even maintain the level of technology that it once had.

Countries that have gone through the racial downgrade transition fully include Haiti (1802) and Zimbabwe (1980). South Africa went through that transition more recently and is on the same technology-loss trajectory. The United States and most of the European Union is presently entering this same process, and the result will be similar.

Many developing countries are actually still in the 2nd stage of the trans model despite having more efficient healthcare and sanitation due to an important factor in population rates not touched on in this video: birth control and family planning. Countries such as India, Uganda, Congo, etc. still have growing populations due to a higher number of children being born surviving through their younger more susceptible years, but in these places most people give birth to large families. The introduction of family planning in these places has largely been rejected due to cultural/social/economic factors. While decreasing mortality rates does have an adverse effect on the Crude Birth Rate, it is still unlikely for a country to transition to stage 4 in the Dem Trans model without common use of birth control.

Transition to stable demographics does not alleviate the problem, but worsens it. That's because a transition depends on rising wealth and development, which in turn go hand in hand with rising resource and energy consumption. We already consume more than is sustainable, and this will only get worse (much worse!) when the developing nations are expected to catch up. Meanwhile, the global population will have grown by another 4 billion, all expecting to get their slice of the cake.

This is a problem that will solve itself, true, but not in a peaceful and quiet manner as suggested here.

This is a great video but its positive message is very oversimplified.  The whole world isn't advancing.  Some places are and some places aren't.  That graph that showed a big reduction in poverty is skewed due to China.  In Africa things are barely improving at all despite lots of aid. 1. The question (Will population growth destroy our way of life?) at the start of the video is left unanswered. I personally think the answer is yes because it is already happening in ways of global warming, depletion of natural resources, deforestation, the extinction of species etc. Those are not things you can just rewind or get back. In my opinion these things are also caused by the fact that the world population has already passed the critical point when you compare it to what this planet has to offer us.
2. Population by itself is not the (only) problem. It is also the amount of resources every person needs to maintain there current lifestyle. This can be translated in the amount of space or land on this planet and there is a limit to that. So less people needing a bigger part of the planet to maintain there lifestyles can be worse than more people needing fewer space.

This video seems to have a more optimistic and comforting conclusion while these two issues are ignored.

Anyone who wants to colonize Mars (cough cough Elon Musk cough cough) should start by colonizing our oceans. And if that runs out, we can always move UNDER water.

interesting vid.  "12 billionth will never be born." implies we'll get to 11 billion.  Nice to have a rosy optimistic picture and all, but saying this in an optimistic that's-awesome! voice is, to me, silly.  There is a desirable maximum number of humans on the planet.  when he says, "More humans means more people to develop our species." in theory that could be good - but if they're confined to this planet then not necessarily.  Would he use that same cheery tone of voice if, "...predicts the 12 trillionth human will never be born."?  the point I'm making is that although it's nice that population growth is slowing down, it's not doing so fast enough to save the biodiversity and ecological viability of the planet.  Those targets can be met, but not if we just let nature run its course, a suggestion that is implicitly made in this vid.  We need to 'develop our species,' NOW, enough to artificially slow our population growth more than nature-running-its-course in my opinion.

An overpopulation problem isn't simply a population growth issue. If resources (Jobs, Food, Housing) can't keep up, that becomes a problem regardless of the growth numbers. A population size problem usually ISN'T because of growth, it's because of resources. I'm not sure when in history the population out grew the resources but there are plenty of examples where the resources dwindled to levels that couldn't support the population.

Yes, the population will correct itself through the war/genocide, perhaps even disease but the reality is there are limited resources even today, just ask any of the millennials out looking for work to pay off their huge education debt. These are population size problems.

The other issue is, the poor have demonstrated they don't reduce their procreation, some even using it to exploit a welfare system that basically pays them to have children. This growth leads to a population that votes for more handouts and resources that they can't earn otherwise because of the job market.

So...we may never get to the 12 billion mark but still the number we have now (that IS growing) is already over burdening the resources we have.

The video doesn't address the key issue of overpopulation, the entire reason why people say that there is an overpopulation problem in the first place; We (humans) are consuming natural resources much faster than nature can replenish them and we're only consuming more as time goes on. Whether or not the population will stabilize in the near future is irrelevant if we can't sustain the population. We're currently dealing with deforestation which leads to the endangering of countless species, overfishing, the destruction of the coral reef and anthropogenic climate change just to name some of the biggest problems. These issues can, for the most part, directly be attributed to overconsumption.

I'll set aside the direct implications of the abovementioned issues for now and focus on the overconsumption issue. At a certain point we won't be able to ignore the effects of our overconsumption anymore, which means that we must put some stringent restrictions on our consumption. The direct consequence of this is that entire economies might fail because they rely so heavily on our overconsumption. So at the very least we can say that overpopulation will have dire economic consequences in the future.

I don't know if you've made a video about this, but the abovementioned points need to be addressed.

The basic trending is right, but the mechanistic interpretation is off and problematic in its attempt to skew everything into an optimistic note.

1) The concept that fertility rates drops in step with a decreases in child mortality is a statistical pattern but not a causal relationship. It ignores the more important social/cultural/economic factors which play the main role in family planning. Acceptance of contraceptives as a family planning options (e.g. religion plays a major role here), what are there economic incentives and disincentives to having a large family? These factors vary dramatically from country to country. Its not like every family on earth naturally wants 2.5 children (even if they all survive). The video presents this as though it is some kind of natural law. The natural law is given by evolution. The individual who passes their genes onto to the largest number of progeny in the next generation wins. We might be thinking apes, but we have natural drives and the video seems to ignore that.

2) Video ignores the secondary problem of affluence growth that comes with decreases in global poverty. Basically not only are there more people today, but each person alive demands more resources per person in their consumptive habits than in the past. Even under an optimistic situation of leveling the population off at 9.5 Billion by 2050 as per UN census trajectories, the trajectory of affluence increases is speeding up not slowing down at a global level. So, the population size might level off but the resource use intensity will continue to grow well after population is no longer growing.

3) Yes it is true that a larger population produces more geniuses. It is also true that a larger population houses more maniacs, more dullards and more just average folks. Genius dilution is an even more pressing issue in our smother-mother generation today where every kid is a winner. You can have a lot of geniuses in the population but if society can't sort them out and rise them to their potential beyond the dullards you can't bank continued efficiency gains in the technology/food/energy production sectors.

Unfortunately this video does nothing to address the issue of key finite resources. Not gonna lie, I came here as a skeptic and was impressed with the impartiality and reason. But the current issue of overpopulation will only be a non apocalypse if the carrying capacity of the earth remains constant. Phosphorus rock is a good example. It is a necessary ingredient to fertilizer and humanity's primary sources of the mineral have only about 50-100 years worth of the rock left. After phosphorus reserves are gone, so will be 90% of our fertilizer production. So although this video makes a good argument for population to be self limiting, I think it over steps it's own conclusions by claiming that we never need to worry about it ever.

This video may apply in a worldwide view, but it does not work for specific countries (specially "third world"). I have lived in Argentina all my life (I am now 32), and the poor population has only ever increased since I have memory. There has never been such a high amount of people here living in poverty as of today. Emergency settlements (here called "villas") just keep growing more and more, and the poor are indeed reproducing out of control, your average mother in these locations has around 8 to 10 kids, since our government pays a social plan for each kid. Corruption doesnt help either, it just seems to increase as well. At this point, even the villas themselves are running short on space, and you have entire families living on makeshift huts at the the corner of your street. And of course, this whole thing is a sprawling ground for insecurity, you got people from this class stealing, harassing, doing drugs and even murdering you for the equivalent of a bloody dollar. And I just dont see any other country jumping over here to assist the situation, which may be similar or even worst in other countries like Brazil or Venezuela. How can there be a solution for this, if not in the very, very long term?

This is all well and true, but western governments and societies should not be forced to accept people into their society just because of these fears, as this will overpopulate our lands too. Just look at the fertility rate of some of the refugees we take into places like Germany, they will still have more and more kids than the typical German couple. Even in a more comfortable and stable environment these refugees have, they still pump out babies and don't turn their own presence into a producer; because such a high tech society doesn't need more people to sustain their labor... Also, western societies shouldn't actually strain themselves either and feel the need to drain their own ambitions just to fuel others. The industrialization that was really discovered by the west is left as a footprint that others can develop off of into a then modernized world; they don't need us to build it for them.

The problem is that poverty and the value of a human is based off population count, and the more we have the less valuable a human is. Another problem is that technology and autonomous machinery can render millions of humans unemployed, even if the population drops. This is just amplified when we have 10 billion people or so, because automation guarantees people are barred from an income that is marginal to comfortable living and even survival in some cases. The video was presented good, but it seems to imply that certain countries should "pay their dues" to the world under this seemingly globalist viewport of how we should tackle world problems. Yes, overpopulation can become our problem too, but it becomes more of our problem when we think "taking them in" actually will reduce the fertility rates worldwide.

The reason why refugees make it into countries so easily, is because the governments responsible for defining border entry regulations and developing policies to regulate such movement are incompetent and broken. The facts on the internet are also falsely skewered and cherry picked by establishment media to make it seem like the majority of people want refugees and uncontrolled immigration. People think making walls and having enforced borders is morally bankrupt; but it is inevitable to any rational system of government that determines it must control the people coming in to define its ability to govern effectively and maintain national solidarity. You can hand it to the "global citizen" type organizations who have principles of deteriorating national integrity by the injection of such people, to weaken the government in that land.

Only problem is, we can only produce enough food in a sustainable way (i.e. organic farming) for 8 billion people, and that means using 50% of the Earth's surface for farming. So if we, the human species wish to avoid the fate of Easter island, then we not only need to radically decrease carbon emissions, but we must also stabilize the population at, or below 8 billion. The most efficient way for this is providing contraceptives (as well) to the poor women in Africa and India, and secondary education for girls (which is documented to reduce the number of planned children by 3). This way, we can stabilize global population in 10 years.

If we do not succeed, however, collapse will be inevitable. Especially since oil is running out, making the predictions of Malthus viable, as the only reason it failed earlier is because he didn't know of oil (which we are wasting for food production). Oil discoveries peaked in the 60s, and we cannot produce the oil which we haven't yet discovered (obviously). We are so desperate at getting oil already that we destroy forests, excavate the soil underneath, and waste a lot of water to get some oil out of it, and fracking contaminates groundwater. We are destroying forests and using up water, so that we can put even more stress on forests and oceans by emitting more CO2. And the growing population is aspiring to buy even more cars. This is ecological suicide.

The Bell-Curve effect, which is of itself flawed.
The population growth due to higher medical applications and food resources still has a limit, by nature's design in all animals in their environments there comes a apex point where the population exceeds these resources and the population growth stops growing and declines. This decline in population continues until the natural resources can replenish themselves that then triggers a population growth again. Thus starting the cycle all over again.
Now here's why for us humans it's flawed. We passed the apex point, more then a generation ago. our population is still growing when it should have noticeable receded.
This is bad, very bad.
Studies have shown with reindeer placed on an island during the war (for an alternative food resource they never needed and abandoned) the reindeer had so much food their population exploded, as migratory animals they didn't see a need to slow their reproduction, since they were trapped on the island and couldn't migrate, they literally exhausted their food supply instead of following the Bell-Curve effect and have fewer offspring. Because they defied this rule to establish a balance with their environment they starved to death. Not half, nor a majority number to which enough survived to rebuild the population when the food grew back, no. Only four lucky reindeer were able to survive the mass death of thousands.
Four, well that doesn't sound like an extinction right?
Wrong.
With the lack of genetic material came inbreeding, and sickness, then death. The last reindeer was surrounded by a regrowth of food so ample it never knew hunger, nor the company of another of its kind since its mother died. Until it died itself.
There has been many studies, this was only one example. As a species we are dangerously following these poor creatures, to defy the Bell-Curve is to risk becoming extinct ourselves. In our case it will only take the depletion of one resource to make it happen. Electricity, gas, food, clean water, or a single disease to run ramped through our massive population.
Our population has never been so high, same with the crime rate by those trying to survive in our world. Our great grandparents barely gave thought to leaving their homes unlocked when they went out, would anyone do that today? Something to think about.

That video is partly right, but in the objective of creating a positive, optimist point of view, it omitted the fact that most of the developed world now has a fertility rate SIGNIFICANTLY below population replacement levels. Germany for instance has had a fertility rate of just 1,4 child per woman since the 1970s, as a result the 0-4 year-old population in Germany is HALF that of the 50-54 year-olds. If nothing comes to reverse this, most developed cultures are going to essentially vanish in 200 years. Immigration is a stop-gap right now, but if all populations follow the same trend, soon there will be no demographic surplus anywhere to compensate developed countries' demographic deficit. An alternative is that more traditional and religious societies keep having a demographic surplus, eventually replacing secular, modern cultures in the Western world by their own cultures, Western cultures thus disappearing over time by population replacement.

I really doubt this will possible (although I wish it would be so). It’s too late… we are already too much people on earth.
Let me explain: this video is right to say that, when reaching a certain level of development, people stop making children. But we are already 7 billion people, and this is going to be 10 billion very soon. We can stop the growth by making all those people live like occidentals, the good old “American way of life”: Cars, big houses, energy, good food (including lot of meat), good healthcare, retirement plans, education… for the moment, 1 out of 7 billion people on earth are living this way. The 6 remaining billion are consuming the same amount of resources than the 1 billion with the higher standard of living. So this is like 2 billion “happy” people where living on the planet, and we already are consuming way, way too much of resources. Species are declining, peaks are coming (oil, phosphorus, coltan.. you name it), and we are actually using each year 1,5 time the resource the earth can renew. So my question is: how are we going to make 10 billion people live this way? This take the resources of 7,5 planets like Earth, and we only have one. And it has to least perhaps 30 years before it can change the fecundity level of the populations. The Earth will be an overheated, sterile desert before we can reach the “magical” equilibrium point this video is about. Believe me, I would rather believe there is a solution, but frankly speaking I’m not seeing much, and certainly not this one…

The problem with over population, to me, has more to do with overconsumption of resources. As things are right now, development nations burn through a disproportionate number of resources compared to the rest of the world. Even if the population in developed nations declines a little as developing nations slow their population growth, once they fully develop they will consume on par with developed nations which will further strain the Earth's resources. That fact is there is plenty of space for all of humanity to live even within a single state, but there's not enough space for them to live comfortably nor is there enough resources for everyone to live the way Americans live on average.

The best home for humanity is to transition to a resource based economy based on robot labor and an emphasis on building to last and sustainable use of resources. If nothing is taken out of nature that isn't put back in, and if everyone has the same standard of living by virtue of being alive, there would be no problem. I don't expect this would happen thoigh. The people with power will not give it up. The nations consuming won't stop either, and would likely kill other nations long before they even begin to pose a threat to their ability to consume. Then will promptly self destruct.

Well, there is a talk about numbers here, but little is said about resources. It would be interesting, for example, to look at people's environmental footprint and demographic data. More and more folks in countries like India and China are getting to live a "western" kind of life, with the toll that such lifestyle, based on consumption, takes on the planet. What happens if our technological skills are not able to catch up? What will happen in 20 years when a huge middle class emerges, for example, in China? Well, they will demand more goods and services, which means they will need more electricity, plastic, beef, and what not. I see very little progress being done when it comes to climate change and environmental degradation, and now that Mr. Trump has been elected, it will be even worse. We cannot just talk numbers when we talk about demographic change. This matter is strictly tied to resource use and other variables, like that of technology, and environmental issues. It's nice to be positive, but we need to be critical and acknowledge that population growth comes at a cost, and that, if your technological advancements are not enough, it can be disastrous for many.

It's not as easy as you describe it. The biggest mistake of the video is that you misunderstand the character of capitalism, which is essential for this whole process. You described the industrial revolution and how it improved living conditions. But you didn't talk about how the early industrial revolution worsened the living conditions. There is no automatism for the increasing living standards with increasing industrial production. The only reason the living standards became better is that the working class people fight for higher wages, less time of daily work, health care etc. This is what happened in the past. But why did this process didn't take place in so cold development countries? Imperialism of the developed capitalist countries holds down the development of third world countries, so there won't be increasing living standards in those countries. A other thing is that the capitalist development isn't linear, there are periodically occurring economic crises that throw back the development, so your perspective for the future is pretty naiv and sounds like an utopia

Overpopulation
The central flaw in this video is that it assumes, incorrectly, that the problem of overpopulation is solved if the total population eventually levels out.


Population Explosion
The human population has sky-rocketed within the past 3 centuries, increasing approximately ten-fold to over 7 billion and is projected to reach 11 billion by 2100 (01). Even 300 years ago, it had never been higher (02). Every new human on our planet further divides its finite resources and increases our waste output. Eminent geneticist, Professor Steve Jones, has described how “humans are 10,000 times more common than we should be, according to the rules of the animal kingdom” (03).


Disease Incidence
A large population drastically increases the rate of disease transmission for all communicable diseases (04). This holds true even for many non-communicable diseases, such as lung cancer (05). Furthermore, antibiotics represent one of our many finite resources and their over-use is progressively diminishing their effectiveness (06). A 2016 report commissioned by the UK Department of Health found that "at least 700,000 people die every year already from drug-resistant infections... by 2050, 10 million lives a year and a cumulative 100 trillion USD of economic output are at risk due to the rise of drug resistant infections… Even if we manage to reduce the unnecessary use of anti-microbials over the next decade, with a growing world population… the world will need a functioning R&D pipeline of new antimicrobials" (07).

The agricultural requirements of feeding a growing population elevate the risk of zoonotic infections, as livestock populations must also increase. Dr. Lonnie King, a director at the CDC, cites population growth as a "major consideration" among the factors "that are creating the conditions for a perfect microbial storm" (08). Separately, population growth is noted by the CDC as a cause of the global decrease in water quality, another potential source of disease (09). Similarly, outdoor air pollution alone “leads to 3.3 million premature deaths per year worldwide”, a figure that is expected to double by 2050 (10).


Finite Resources
While the most widely recognised non-renewable resources are the fossil fuels, upon which most of our energy consumption depends, there are many others that we are rapidly exhausting. Current groundwater usage is “unsustainable” (11), while phosphate, a key ingredient in fertiliser, is expected to “run out in 50 years”, though our need for it will be even greater then as population growth "will require food production to at least double by 2050" (12).


Animal Extinctions
Zoologists warn that “the number of species that have gone extinct in the last century would [normally] have taken, depending on the vertebrate taxon, between 800 and 10,000 years to disappear”. The rate of extinctions closely mirrors human population growth (13). For example, “rapidly expanding human populations” have caused gorillas and chimpanzees to be “pushed to the brink of extinction” (14).


Climate Change
A 2009 study in The Lancet notes that “climate change is the biggest global health threat of the 21st century” (15). As with finite resource expenditure, climate change synergistically exacerbates disease transmission, particularly in the area of mosquito-borne pathogens. For example, by 2085, “about 5–6 billion people (50–60% of the projected global population) [will] be at risk of dengue transmission, compared with 3·5 billion people, or 35% of the population, if climate change did not happen" (16).

Anthropogenic climate change largely results from increased CO₂ emissions due to fossil fuel combustion (17). Procreation is a frequently overlooked contributor to CO₂ emissions; in the US for example, “each child adds about 9441 metric tons of carbon dioxide to the carbon legacy of an average female, which is 5.7 times her lifetime emissions” (18). In fact, "slowing population growth could provide 16–29% of the emissions reductions suggested to be necessary by 2050 to avoid dangerous climate change” and the benefits would be cumulative, such that by the end of the century, there could be reductions in “total emissions from fossil fuel use by 37–41%” (19). Carbon emissions over the next few decades will have irreversible consequences “for the next ten millennia and beyond” (20).


Conclusion
Animal populations oscillate between peaks and troughs over time, with the transition from peak to trough characterised by considerable suffering, in the form of famine, disease and predation. All indications are that the unchecked growth of the human population will elicit a concomitant level of suffering for humans.

Leading journals describe how “the inexorable demographic momentum of the global human population is rapidly eroding Earth’s life-support system” (21). Finite, polluting fossil fuels account for >85% of global energy consumption and 15-30% of this energy “is used to simply supply food for 7.2 billion people" (22). Waste production and resource consumption would occur at roughly one thousandth of the current rate, were our population a thousand times smaller.

A crowded journey on public transport is sufficient to enlighten us as to the inverse relationship between population size and quality of life. There is almost no benefit to increasing our population.


References

(02) E.M. Murphy, 1989, World Population: Toward the Next Century. Population Reference Bureau.

(03) Prof. Steve Jones, 7/10/2008, University College London - Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment. Human evolution is over, says UCL academic. UCL Lunch Hour Lecture.

(04) Arneberg et al., 1998, Host densities as determinants of abundance in parasite communities. Proceeds of the Royal Society B. 265(1403), 1283-1289.

This optimistic scenario leaves a few details out. Notably, the fact that ideologies formed in the earlier stages of civilization growth have a tendency to linger past the era where they were originally useful, and in fact help to halt progress into a new stage. A decrease in child mortality affects everyone, since we mandate that the government intervene to stop any babies from dying. But we don't mandate that the government prevent families from continuing to have immense numbers of children, nor do we mandate that the government give all of those children jobs. Demographic forces might cause those problems to partially solve themselves, but when legal and religious mandates are applied absolutely, we need more than the squishy tendencies of statistical probability to act as a counterbalance.
