This video is omitting some important facts and misleading people on certain parts of the overpopulation argument. No one has suggested that the world will somehow blow up because of continued population growth. What people have noticed is that the planet is under more and more strain with each passing decade, and population growth is a factor in it. It is a factor in global warming, for example.

The video notes that the UN forecasts the 12th billion human will never be born. So that means potentially 4 billion more people added to the current population. If we are to trust climate scientists human induced climate change is proceeding at an exponential rate, in other words time is not unlimited to solve this problem, and if we are simply going to let the population level out "naturally", it may actually be too late to salvage a decent planet free from things like conflict and the such.

So the issue is not that it's overblown, because it's not. It is simply misrepresented as an imminent armageddon, but the threat is actually very real from continued population growth, continued use of fossil fuels by said population, continued use of massive animal agriculture, etc. It could certainly threaten the stability of life on our planet, and that is IMO very serious.

I've often pondered the effects of modern medicine on our own evolution. Although I would hate to lose someone I care for because of a disease, the reality is that if we stopped treating these illnesses, humans would slowly develop immunity to them, many would die, however, long term humanity would benefit from this course of action. Take c sections for example, as has recently been reported, If we did not perform this procedure when deemed necessary to save the mother or child, the genetic faults that cause this would slowly eradicate themselves due to the fact that that these genetic lines would cease to exist. Because we perform this procedure the number of c sections has risen dramatically over the past century due to the fact that these genetic lines are allowed to continue. This is true of all genetic disorders and/or birth defects. Because of modern medicine we are facing issues with antibiotic resistance, higher rates of cancer, autism, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, heart disease, and may others. Now I'm not saying we should just give up and let everyone die, we won't have a choice, we've already opened Pandora's box, nature will create new challenges that we will not be able to overcome, nor will we be as genetically fit to fight these new problems because we have been weakened by our own medicines. All we have done is delayed the inevitable and possibly overpopulated the earth in the process. When the other shoe drops it will be much worse for us than if we'd just let nature take its course to begin with, and now instead of a few million deaths from an outbreak we will be looking at billions.

Without being competitive enough, how will you even afford anything that the tech progress will have to offer? Will you even have time to enjoy anything?
Of course, the number of small\medium businesses will also increase ( = more jobs), but the number of "working" people still will be much bigger. The only way to survive and live a good\normal live would be either by being an entrepreneur yourself, or by being a very competitive employee.

There is a very important variable you failed to mention before you say there is no "apocalyptic prophesy" when it comes to overpopulation: resources are not infinite. 7.4 Billion people will leave (are leaving) an imprint on our very limited resources. Our effect on the planet (waste, pollution, over fishing, CO2 emissions, etc..) should not be ignored.

It's unreasonable to assume that developments in Western societies will be mirrored elsewhere, and also unreasonable to assume current trends will continue indefinitely into the future.  This video is ideologically committed to a utopian vision of the future based on these flawed assumptions.  I think some pessimism is justified simply on the basis that resources are limited, yet 4 billion years of evolution on Earth compels our reproduction and competition for those resources.  Those people who conciously and concientiously limit their own reproduction will be outreproduced and outcompeted by those who for genetic or environmental reasons choose not to.  Whatever mutations predispose humans to continue reproducing in the face of dire warnings will be propagated.  That inevitability essentially seals our fate.

"Emancipation of women"
Let us take a look at the term "emancipation".

Definition
1) the fact or process of being set free from legal, social, or political restrictions; liberation.
This is somewhat true, no doubt conjuring notions of movements like the Suffrage movement. What if I told you that in the UK (A nation heavily featured in this video) men only received universal suffrage about half a dozen years before women. That many of the freedoms women were excluded from, so where most men. That during the height of what's known as the most stifled and controlled society (the Victorian era), that the most powerful person in the world was a woman.

2) the freeing of someone from slavery.
Given the influence American culture has on the world, this is the often recognised definition. That throughout history women were no more likely to be slaves than men.

So I'll leave you all with one question. What were women emancipated from exactly? How have old fashioned (traditional) norms been harsher on women than men?

1) The human population is projected to reach ~11 billion by 2100 (01).


2) While you're correct that the potential for a faster rate of technological development is perhaps the ONLY benefit of this, simply in virtue of there being more humans...

a) While pumping money into higher education institutions may mean more money goes to research, there is actually no evidentiary basis to support the supposed role of higher education: to enhance the productivity of the workforce.

b) Many, perhaps most of the problems our species faces and which require technological solutions are results of overpopulation and/or would not be a problem without it. For example, antibiotics represent one of our many finite resources and their over-use is progressively diminishing their effectiveness (02). We wouldn't need to invent new ones if we didn't have so many people and so many farm animals being pumped with them.


3) We are already overpopulated. Eminent geneticist, Professor Steve Jones, has described how “humans are 10,000 times more common than we should be, according to the rules of the animal kingdom” (03). Continuing with the example of antibiotics, at the time of a report commissioned by the UK Dept. of Health, 700,000 people died each year from drug-resistant infections. "by 2050, 10 million lives a year and a cumulative 100
trillion USD of economic output are at risk due to the rise of drug resistant infections" (04).

Conclusion
A new study has just recently been released highlighting the fact that expanding human populations are causing the 6th mass extinction and it follows multiple other studies that make the same point. Put most succinctly, every new child on the planet further divides Earth's finite resources and increases our waste output. Every animal population oscillates between peaks and troughs. Humans are currently shooting up a massive peak. When population levels inevitably fall (down the other side of that peak) due to disease, famine, and in our case, anthropogenic climate change etc, this will be characterised by enormous suffering... all due to utterly needless and almost entirely unbeneficial population expansion.


(01) Gerland et al., 2014, World population stabilization unlikely this century. Science. 346(6206), 234-237.

(02) Spellberg et al., 2008, The Epidemic of Antibiotic-Resistant Infections: A Call to Action for the Medical Community from the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clinical Infectious Diseases. 46(2), 155-164.

(03) Prof. Steve Jones, 7/10/2008, University College London - Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment. Human evolution is over, says UCL academic. UCL Lunch Hour Lecture.

(04) Jim O'Neill, 2016, Tackling Drug-Resistant Infections Globally: The Review on Antimicrobial Resistance.

"The minimum amount of agricultural land necessary for sustainable food security, with a diversified diet similar to those of North America and Western Europe (hence including meat), is 0.5 of a hectare per person. This does not allow for any land degradation such as soil erosion, and it assumes adequate water supplies. Very few populous countries have more than an average of 0.25 of a hectare. It is realistic to suppose that the absolute minimum of arable land to support one person is a mere 0.07 of a hectare–and this assumes a largely vegetarian diet, no land degradation or water shortages, virtually no post-harvest waste, and farmers who know precisely when and how to plant, fertilize, irrigate, etc. [FAO, 1993]"

http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.LND.ARBL.HA.PC

If a city of 10 million people only recycles 90% of the NPKs & micronutrients of all organic products it consumed in a year, next year, it will only be able to produce about 90% of the food. Meaning, there will only be enough food for 9 million. If that corresponds to just enough for the calories, protein, and other nutrients, either all slowly starve to death, or, they have to decide to kill 1 million people. "Nutrient cycle" basic math.

This means no sewage. If the food spends more carbon energy than the calories it traps, than you have a "carbon cycle" problem. If roads or infrastructure break, you have a "nutrient cycle" problem. There's no such thing as a flawless infraestrutura for this.

Nah, deep evolutionary time in totally different environments has created stable differences in reproductive patterns among separate breeding populations. It's very clear in America, for example, that people of other races growing up in the same environments behave differently. The evidence of geographic specialization is clear in both anatomy and psychology. Your model fails to account for the industrial revolution in the first place. We were on a eugenic trajectory and then took a turn into the dysgenic with the advent and proliferation of industry. It's circular reasoning to attribute our type K reproductive strategy to the industrial revolution (which is totally absurd, as industrialization has a strong r-selection effect) without even considering the causal origins of the forces which brought us from savagery to civility and primitive to industrial.

Btw, you really believe the "dark ages" mythos? Everything was shit before or lord and savior, science? That's scientism, or the psuedo-religious misapplication of science, not actual science. Let's contextualize your nature = doom and gloom account of history with some geography. The Pleistocene epoch was the impetus for the foray out of Africa, and along with it came the advent of fire. The environment of those who would become Europeans was a frigid tundra, not the humid jungle and sun-baked savannah that they left. The environment that spawned Europeans (with their longer, narrower nostrils and shorter limbs) was a much cooler one than that of other peoples, and their mere anatomy can tell us that. Their nostrils adapted to the icy hostility of the North, and they were selected for stockier limbs which are more resistant to frostbite. They also developed more slow-twitch muscle fibers, which conserves energy for slow, long, deliberate work in the cold.

Adapting to random predation and disease, and a relative abundance of carbohydrates by comparison, Africans have more quick-twitch fibers, which help them dominate in running sports, and higher, peaked calves which help them to dominate in jumping sports. They don't fair so well with swimming sports, however, and this is because of their greater bone density. Whites, particularly Nordic peoples, also dominate strongman competitions (not bodybuilding, it's extreme weightlifting). These geographical selection pressures acted over deep evolutionary time to shape the body and mind of our people. This is why whites have a more deliberate disposition while Africans trend toward impulsivity. This exemplifies k- vs r-selection, respectively. K-selection is the primary causal force for the development of industry. I'm sitting on a lot more evidence than this, I'm only giving you a taste. I haven't even gotten into the anatomical evidence for polyandrous r-selection among natives to the global South.

The problem I have with this video is there's a very big fucking problem with the way people interpret the fact that population growth is "stagnant or declining".

Growth is not declining. The rate of growth is declining. This means that we're still growing at an exponentially increasing number every year, even if the rate of that growth lessens each time.

Just to illustrate the point with an exaggerated example:

1. a jump from 10 to 15: 50% growth
2. a jump from 1 million to 1.25 million: Only a 25% growth
3. a jump from 1 billion to 1.1 billion: only a 10% growth

See the problem? In that trend you could say "population growth has slowed down by a whopping 40%", which is a meaningless stat when you also consider that it's jumped from a factor of adding only 5 extra compared to 1 billion extra. We're growing faster than ever in increasingly huge numbers, even if the rate of growth is shrinking.

So when you hear things like "1% growth isn't a big deal". when you take into account the actual population growth of the USA (currently 0.7%), that means that the USA will have double the population in around 100 years. When you look at the world rate (currently 1.13) it's around 65 years doubling time. And that means going from 7.4 billion people to 14.8 billion people in that time.

Think about that. In 65 years (assuming everything else is equal, which it isn't), there will be nearly 15 thousand million more people on this Earth.

This is a totally falacious argument.
(1) There will ALWAYS be a large population of poor having too many babies. Even if all of the countries in the world today miraculously rise out of poverty (which will never happen) there will be always be countries falling back into poverty, like Venezuela is now. As the crazy birth rates return, population explodes and becomes significant driver of world population growth once again.
(2) Simple math: a small population experiencing exponential growth will soon surpass an initially larger population experiencing sub-exponential growth. So the fact that growth in Western developed countries has stopped is irrelevant. There will always be places with high birth rates, and those will dominate the numbers. e.g. as the muslim population explodes, the contribution of the low-birth-rate Western cultures no longer matters and the global population growth is determined by the family size of average muslims. If growth eventually slows amongst muslims for some reason, a new seed of exponential growth will appear in a new group who will soon dominate the growth. The diversity and size of the global population ensures that such seeds of exponential growth will always exist.

Exponential growth will continue until resources are exhausted, i.e. the socialist western states collapse, or until stopped by lethal pandemic disease, which increases super-linearly in probability with size of interacting population.

Also, the claim that “we’re not special” and all countries will go thru the same 4 stages is total BS. Most of the countries that are destitute now will never rise out of poverty.

This is a totally naive prediction. Western countries were able to transition due to plentiful natural resources. We still consume a disproportionate amount of the world's remaining oil, metals and other renewable and non-renewable resources. Also, Western countries were growing from a relatively low base population whereas countries like China and India exploded from an already huge population base.

This means transition to stage 4 for most of today's developing countries is likely unattainable if they continue to adopt Western-style consumerism (which they do). It is likely many will collapse due to environmental exhaustion and resource depletion before they develop enough for the natural processes to reduce population growth.

Massive pessimism in unwarranted, but so is this kind of naive optimism. There is no way Africa will be able to sustain populations projected by the U.N. In many of its countries, living standards are not rising because population grows faster than the economy. This video completely glossed over this major problem.

This overpopulation theory doesn't take in the concern many people are currently expressing in regards to Nature. Even if the birth rates stabilize eventually... There will still be the issue where humans end up spreading their fingers everywhere, disrupting nature in the process to make products for humanity or simply to live there. For example, instead of leaving a lake alone. They will build a house next to it. Instead of leaving a region alone ,they will build a house or use another purpose for it.

Sure, there are so called national parks. But many people opt for houses and similar which leads to a more wide spread population but also much more surface area. As for the people declining subtly noted eventually in the well made video. I doubt that will occur. I think the people count will steadily rise. Maybe not in an explosive nature.

There is also the issue of Food. This issue can't be ignored when looking at Over population theory. With rising status of the people, it also results in more welfare in the food production. Taking the consumption of a normal younger individual who will become the later generation eventually. It will lead to a rise of food per day in consumption. This is not because they go obese but the healthier trend of exercise tied together with good food. By exercising, one spends more energy and need to consume more in the process.

This results in a healthier human but rising need for food production. We simply do not have the surface area or investments in battling this.

There is aquaponics which tends to work well, but there is a lack of available investments in this sector for now. We can build several store buildings on a slanted angle to create an optimal surface area for growing a certain crop on less square metre usage. But this would only work for the essentials like fruit/vegetables.

Some plants and trees would still require space for produce. Some simply wouldn't thrive in a controlled environment without certain 'pest'.

So even if the population slow down in rise. There will still be the issue of the fact that we are conquering much of the nature and if we are to believe WHO and certain other action groups. They want us to preserve other species in their wild environments. Zoo animals are considered domesticated to certain extent.

This means, we still have over population issues in certain factors. The only real way to hinder this, would be to eliminate cities to open up more space. Make less cities/settlements exist in the world.

This video is only really true if you discount the effect of inferior cultures (notice how I said culture, not race: cultures can accept people of any color) as well as the (to be fair completely natural) tendency for capitalistic societies to favor growth over nearly all other prospects. Less babies being born = less sales of products for babies, etc. Thus, logically, the smart thing for a big corporation that creates these products and relies so much on growth is to ensure that that growth continues forever. An easy way to do this is to grab people from populations that are still in the first/second stage of birth/death numbers (i.e. the need to produce many kids to have some survive) and import them to the places where the companies operate. Combine that with the natural urge of western people to help others, and you have the migrant crisis perfectly explained.

Additionally, this video doesn't at all account for transplanting many people from one tier to another, higher one. Had there been a stage 4, stabilized populated nation during the 1800's, there sure as hell would have been massive waves of Europeans looking for a better life and thus massive breeding from them before they settled down in a couple generations. Oh wait, that did happen- The United States had a MASSIVE influx of European immigrants around the turn of the century, and only really died down after both World Wars killed tens of millions of European people each. Integration was very tough for the first couple of generations- and that's with people with roughly the same western cultural values.

This is BS!  He's measuring the wrong rates.  It's birth rate vs. death rate.  That is how population growth is technically measured.  The birth rate is more than twice the death rate = overpopulation!  Case closed!

This is one of my least favorite Kurzgesagt ever, it had very little substance.
Basically summed up. "Exponential growth of progress happened in Britain, leading to huge rise and plateau of population during the industrial revolution. Industrialization is spreading and becoming quicker due to contributions by developed nations, this is also leading quality of life gains across our entire planet. Population growth is no problem, it's just a phase in a much bigger perspective!"

Why did you ignore The 5th stage of the pyramid? It's incredibly relevant; that's a pretty big topic to leave out.
Consider most countries are in the 5th stage of the pyramid. 118/224 countries have negative population growth (<2.10). You even glossed over the mechanisms of why birthrate decreases as we progress up the pyramid. Is it social, cultural, economic, you didn't even casually mention it.

You could have mentioned a myriad of topics that could have been interesting, rates of jobs in developing vs developed nations, immigration and birthrate, the role of automation in caring for an older generation.
You even kind of hinted to it in the end credits. That chef could be completely replaced with a robot, it's already doing the more complicated part of her job. An automation video would have been awesome, compared with your 12,017 video which was a modern stance on the BC/BCE debate which has been rehashed for at least 300 years.

With the increased pace of your videos, from 1 per month to 4 per month, your videos are at a worse quality. People didn't go to Kurzgesagt because you spewed content out an a blistering rate, we came in droves because your content precisely boiled down an idea to it's quintessential natural without losing it's potency. These last 2 episodes honestly feel phoned in, almost like filler. Maybe this is just a phase, or my a flaw with my own perception. I hope you can return to producing, what I perceive to be, a superior educational video.

No, we are not overpopulating. Maybe the makers of this video would kindly see the world TFR rates? In Germany, they are welcoming the migrant baby boom because their population is below replacement.

There is no 'human explosion'. That line was used by Paul Ehrlich in the 1970's, and look what happened. The world TFR rate is 2.41.

Unless, of course, you advocate population reduction in Africa and the Middle East, where they have twenty children apiece for the latter and twelve for the former. But that would be racist, wouldn't it? You wouldn't dare advocate population reduction on poor Third Worlders, would you? The European should cut his birthrate even more despite it being below replacement, but the man with four wives and twenty three kids in Germany doesn't get a peep from you.

See the Population Research Institute on this. We are not overpopulated, so your cute little animations aren't including world TFR rates or anything from the UN population division. You are using the High Variant and Constant Variant rates, which do suggest upward population increase. But the low variant says the human population will peak in either 2030 or 2050 and decline.

But those facts are inconvenient, aren't they? I ask again: will you encourage smaller families for Muslims and Africans? Or are the Europeans and East Asians forced to cut their birthrates even more?

While I have, too, learned of the demographic transition model in college courses, I only partially agree with this video. In an abbreviated form of my argument:

-While population growth will eventually slow and stabilize, it is simply not possible, if society continues onward like it is now, that everyone will come out of poverty. This is for two reasons: poverty is defined based on current economic conditions, and thus can never be eliminated, as not everyone will be equal, and, there is simply not enough to go around. 7 billion people living like an average American... it makes me cringe.
-The argument that 'more people means more progress' has been advanced for centuries now. Technology has always been invented to solve issues, yet it constantly creates more. And even if all current and future problems are solved, it is humanity's nature to want for more. Problems = purpose. If humans never developed technology, either through will or some higher design, we would be forced to adapt to the planet, not shape it. This would mean more harmony between us and the environment.

However, I hope your video is correct. I hope we can all live like slobs, raise a moderate family on a decent plot of land, always have food to eat, and all focus on being a planet, instead of individual people. But knowing humans, this seems unlikely.

The true problem isn't that we'll live in some Soylent Green runaway population explosion, rather it's the unanswered question 'does the earth have the sustainable carrying capacity so support 10,000,000,000 humans?' I'm skeptical that there are enough resources and the ability to absorb human activity on the planet to indefinitely support our current population much less a 35% increase. This isn't just how much oil there is but how much CO(2) (and methane) we disperse. How what we're having to do now to keep soil fertile long term may not be sustainable over a century. Yes as yet un-conceived of technological advancement will save us.... until it doesn't. While I'll agree the doom sayers are wrong I nonetheless don't think the 'everything's fine and all roses' crowd has any stronger argument.

Overpopulation isn't just about people and space, (not that the video suggested this, but this is to people in the comments) it's about resources. If you have more people than you can feed and get clean water, you are overpopulated. If you have more people than you can house, you are overpopulated. In our modern world, if you have more people than you can supply gas, fuel, and other energy to, you might be overpopulated.
The point is that resources are really the key here. Even in the big cities, we manage for now... And as we move into the new paradigm of AR and VR we will lessen much of our demands on space and nature, like phones, the computer and the internet have reduced certain strains, so will these new technologies.
The nation that invests in supporting it's people to become more self-sufficient (growing their own food, harvesting rainwater, capturing energy from the sun etc) will have the next leg up in the world.

I'm kind of disappointed to see such an enormous oversight in a Kurzgesagt video.  What they did not mention is that, even though birth rates decrease as a country modernizes, their resource consumption per capita explodes.  A single American produces dozens of times the emissions as a person in a developing country, and that's not going to appreciably decrease.  It's at the point where, if you live in a developed country, each successive child increases your carbon footprint by a factor of six at the very least, according to a recent study by Oregon State University.  So saying "more people means more people working to solve the world's problems" is invalid, because the problem isn't on its own too many people, it's too much consumption.  Fewer people can still consume a great deal more.

Our world isn't overpopulated, it actually was shown that if everyone in the world stood shoulder to shoulder we'd only take up the state of Nevada. Our problem is that people are clustered into small areas causing a lack of space. If we actually used the entire earth we'd have plenty of room, sadly though climate tends to restrict this.

I hear the statistic of extreme poverty being reduced all the time, but it's worth pointing out that the World Bank's definition of extreme poverty is living on $1.90 per day or less. That's not a high bar to get over, and it could just mean that many formerly extremely impoverished people have just barely made it over that arbitrary bar.

Also, people who promote overpopulation as an inevitability seem to forget why the human population started growing in the first place: each new human raises the carrying capacity of all of humanity by slightly more than the amount of resources they consume. Originally, this meant supplying physical labor, but now encompasses intellectual and creative talents as well.

Average of 2.2 kids is still exponential growth. Unless you can get it to ≤2 then there is still exponential growth.

Also, this overlooks evolution. Those with genetic tendencies to want (achieve) more children will spread their genes more successfully that those who want less of them (or otherwise have less). This would imply that even in a wealthy society with good health care and education system, people will, over time, tend toward a higher fertility (having more kids).

Hence overpopulation is still a real problem, but yes: the graph of population over time is unlikely to represent a simple exponential function.

Population in some more developed countries such as Japan have actually been decreasing in recent years as their education, health care, life expectancy, and standards of living are so high. Japan also has an inverted population pyramid, and is in the theoretical stage 5 of the demographic transition model where the death rates in a country slowly begin to exceed the birth rates. This will lead to several economic issues as Japan's dependency ratio will increase and there will be a decrease in the labor force. Scale this to the global economy with several other Western countries advancing into stage 5 and there could be many economic problems in the future as a result of decreasing population and a shortage of labor. Although I doubt these potential issues will be anywhere near the issue of a human population of 12 billion

Hear my global warming theory. CO2 and gases aren't the real reason. I think the real reason is energy consumption.

Let me give an example.

Imagine you are in a glass room so the source of heat for you is the sun outside. The sunlight will enter and radiate back so there will be equilibrium. And you then turn on the heater, the room get warmer than usual.

You can understand where I am going with the example. The earth used to get sunlight energy and reflect back so there is equilibrium. However, nowadays we use the extra stored energy like the heater in the example so our earth is getting warmer than usual. Just imagine that nights used to be dark, now we are producing more heat everyday.

According to a book I've read, most peripheral countries are currently in the demographic trap. Meaning they are stuck in the second or third phase (transitional phase) of the demographic transition. And as far as I know, it is the Demographic Transition Theory. It is a theory for a reason, the book says that experts argue that the demographic transition theory mostly only works for core countries and less to most (not all) peripheral countries. This means the population is still rising because peripheral countries have high birth rate and low death rates. Yes... Finally a video that isn't about the "sad side" of the truth.

About the capability of the planet sustain a entire world... The world CAN sustain a populations of 10... 12 billion in a high developed state of living (high education, well fed, good health care etc) in a "4th stage"of the pyramid. People tend to make a confusion of the resources needed to this with the resources needed to sustain an "american way of life". We DON'T NEED the american way of life!

All the 12bi can have, besides the basic (education, food, health), access to transportation (even cars), trips to other countries, access to communication (basically internet), etc. But we can't expect all to have a SUVs with 7 liters V8 in the garage to use 90% of the time with one person only, lots of wast food, etc... But a typical familly (of the interior) can have 2 cars, intenet, health, good food.

It's all about eficiency!

A 80's Chev Suburban 4x2 (typical SUV of USA) uses 15liters or more to travell 100km (6-7km/l or 15mpg) in a highway... A modern one can make the same travel using 10 liters (10km/l or 23mpg)... And with much more confort. But we need a 3tons small house to use in the day-to-day locomotions??? A modern compact car can make 5 L/100Km (20km/l or almost 50mpg)!!!
And this high efficiency is present in all the modern equipments and vehicles from the LED light to the Maersk Triple E class container ships, all our machines are more efficient than in a VERY RECENT past. Refrigerators, air conditioners, trucks, trains, airplanes, computers!!!

If we add this the renewable energy sources and their accessories (like batteries) cheaper like never, and with prices still dropping, high efficiency soil ocupation (post-modern agriculture, with a high diversity of food produced near the consumer) and post-modern city development (without the "dicotomy" center x suburban areas so defined) and we can reach the equilibrium without a pandemonium drawned by some "horseman of the Apocalypse".

Yes, we are something about a century or even more to achieve a global high human development populational equilibrium, and we need to survive our cultural adolescence (tribal, cultural and religious wars, extreme poverty and concentrate poverty in large regions like southeast asia, africa, south and central america, etc). But I think is more likely to all the mankind die of a extreme intolerance war than by a overpopulation induced problem (even a war by finite resources, like water, with would be overpopulation induced war in my opinion).

Equilibrium and eficienty are the key words.

You didn't telled us about the real demographic  problem humanity will probably have to deal with within the next 50 years: The 4th stage isn't the end of the process, it is followed by a 5th stage, in wich the birth rate drops under the death rate, causing a massive aging of the affectet societies (wich currently happens in most western countries). This is the real thing we have to worry about, overpopulation is not that big problem most people think.

This is a pretty blindly optimistic video. It does not take into account that populations that stagnate also tend to be replaced, population movements are not always a good thing because "more people" does NOT mean "more educated and healthy beneficial people," it literally just means "more people," and it certainly ignores the effect that replacing people with technology has had on developed countries like the United States.

Maybe population growth will slow down, but that is just one tiny facet of the overall, extremely complex human problems facing us. What will a world of slowed growth LOOK like? Is it the world you want, or some other country wants? Who will populate this world, from where, what will their ideas be like? You can't just stop at "oh, well, we'll never reach 12 billion so there's nothing wrong."

Please don't pretend that just because you watch this five minute video you actually know how to fix the Earth, or that there's nothing to worry about.

This might be the first "in a nutshell" vid that seems to ignore some of the current data. As they rightly point out: population explosion isn't going to happen. But birth rates are actually much lower (and lowering the world over). We are currently below replacement levels. The only reason the total population is still increasing is due to "demographic momentum" (essentially old people are living much longer so there are more people in total for the moment, regardless of the lower birth rate). Once the older generation are gone the world's population will actually shrink.

Still good that the population explosion idea is being debunked as it is sadly used to justify all manner of arguments relating to refugees, abortion, euthanasia etc.

In a way, overpopulation isn't as much of a problem as overconsumption. Theoretically if everyone merely consumed less unrenewable resources and manufactured goods, then the problem might solve itself. however then we have to factor in the part where if people consume less goods, producers will in turn slow production to match market demand and avoid surplus. Furthermore, an increase in consumption will cause producers to find alternative and renewable methods to create goods and match market demand, thus the problem of "overconsumption vs overpopulation" is inherently null because they are the same thing and everything balances out in the end yay

I have no reason to argue that you are incorrect that population growth will soon halt, however that ignores the fact that the population growth that has already occurred is wildly unsustainable with our current technology. Additionally, even if our technology were to improve to a level needed to comfortably support more than 7 billion, it still would be preferable to not have such a high population. I'm not saying that a person's value is determined by how they can advance society, but the notion that the more people you have, the more people you have advancing society is fundamentally flawed. The majority of working people only sustain society, not advance it. If instead of letting population naturally grow to the largest it can, it were to be reduced, the abundance of resources would allow not only for a reduction of conflict, but a shift in focus from struggling to sustain, to making actual progress in the realms of technology and individual consciousness.

This is an interesting video but I think it fudges the facts quite a bit. Population in stage 4 isn't stable. It's shrinking. There are also many countries where development isn't really happening. It would have been helpful to at least mention in the video that we're not here for the first time. Finally it's important to consider what a shrinking population does for the demographic, social, and economic situation in a country. Europe and especially Russia are great case studies for this. Russia has managed to reverse their population from shrinking to growing. How? ;-)

A completely biased and irresponsible video, saying we have nothing to worry about with 7.4 billion people and increasing rapidly. Several factual errors.
1. All the prophecies of doom could still come true, we are in massive overshoot.
2. High birth rates are still happening despite wealth in some countries, e.g. Middle East
3. With fewer deaths and less infant mortality, population is still increasing
4. Developed countries are still increasing e.g. UK and USA.
5. Average of 2.5 children still leads to growth.
6. Says ‘the rate of growth will slow’. But there is still growth.
7. States that reduced growth is due to ‘progress'. This progress equals increased consumption, which adds to all environmental problems.
8. Percentage in poverty may be lower, but 80% of population lives on less than 10 dollars a day. 1.3 billion are living in extreme poverty.
9. UN population forecasts vary by several billion.

We should be doing everything we can to reduce population growth.

there is a slight issue with having such a highly educated work force, the lack of cheap labor.

The only reason Doctors get paid so much is 2 fold, they took alot of resources to produce (education and all) and that use of resources is hard so there are not many.

Like with any economic model it can be seen as supply and demand. now think that we are increasing the number of doctors, the supply goes up but the demand is not going up as fast.

This would mean that unskilled labor becomes harder to find and people are less willing to work for those wages since they have a higher level of education then "Some burger flipper!". We can solve this issue with tech, automation, robotics, and drones but that only works after a certain point, once the price of labor goes higher then the price of those techs. This is the issue we are seeing now in the USA, the banks screwing up royally just shined the light on it sooner then it should have been.

And the other problem is this, there are not unlimited resources for this tech. Rare earth metals are called that for a reason and our robotics use them, heck alot of tech does, so there is only so much on Earth to go around. Now we can find sources off Earth but considering we have not been to the moon in so long i do not see us getting to the Belt anytime soon. So we have a problem with this and it amazes me that the UN could not see that coming. Tech is great, people not dying is great, people living better lives is also great, but we have to ask what the effects are and how to deal with them before they become big issues.

While this is a step in the right direction, it overlooks two important factors: carrying capacity and critical mass.

Critical mass is the fact that there are too many people to start with, so even if they are having fewer children, they are still having a lot. A billion people having two kids is just as bad as a hundred million people having 5 kids.

Carrying capacity is the resources that the planet can reasonably provide for the population. The only way we can provide enough food for 7 billion people is though highly aggressive, unsustainable agricultural practices. We use a year of the earth's resources in 8 months, meaning we have to take from reserves to make up the difference. The optimum population for Earth is between 2 and 3 billion. The maximum carrying capacity is around 6 billion.

There are several things wrong here.

#1 - Where is all of this statistical data and this 4 phase model coming from? You should really start up a references section for these.
#2 - Humans have not been around only since the 18th century. Also, that is a very compressed version of the industrial revolution. That thing was so huge that, yes, underdeveloped countries may STILL be benefiting now from it happening. So how can you base your theory on this effect lasting forever?
#3 - Time progresses, even for the planet. Oil runs out, climate changes. Massive weapons are created. The internet. Stop acting as if there ever really was a way to predict the future, in either pessimistic or optimistic direction.
#4 - How does this model hold up for ancient greece/rome/egypt? They kind of had better odds, too. Yes, population growth is slowing, explosive growth happens mostly in the developing world, not the developed world, and as a result of more world being developed, growth is slowing, but even on the very generous estimate that at the end of this process we will end up with 8.5 billion people, we still already have too many people where we stand right now. In order to feed over 7 billion people, we needed to convert large areas of land into farmland, and use large volumes of potentially or certainly harmful fertilizers and pesticides, not to mention the over-fishing. Then to have somewhere to put all of those people, we needed to urbanize far too much land area, to allow transportation, we dug canals, made roads, and laid railroad tracks, to furnish these people's homes, we mine continuous and massive amounts of resources, to provide energy to this many people is a massive and ongoing problem, to build infrastructure for internet access for all of these people is yet another ongoing problem, and no matter what you do, a population this size will generate an unmanageable amount of waste.

I'm not afraid of continued explosive growth, because it is literally impossible, I'm afraid of the people we already have.

Honestly I'm a little disappointed in this video, I was hoping they would have a more in depth and unique video analyzing how population growth could change due to new technologies like crispr. A fully developed world is not sustainable. Furthermore, we are likely about to see a large decline in the death rate, crispr alone has the capability to more or less eliminate diseases such as malaria, remove viruses such as hiv from human cells, and even combat cancer. In a nutshell themselves discussed the possibility of targeting aging related genes with crispr. A decline in worldwide death rate and/or an increase in life expectancy with a steady birthrate will lead to population growth and ultimately an unsustainably large population.

The only issue to keep in mind is that this deals with global population, and not regional. You can still have a regional population problem, but it would still be temporary in the long run. The problem comes with resource renewal and if you have a population surplus in a region with resource deficits...well, you'll run into some problems--especially in situations where a resource is not renewable, like oil, or slower to recover, like aquifers. That said, you really have to be in a very specific place to worry about this kind of thing. If you're sitting in the middle of North America, you really don't need to be worried about this sort of thing say for a general environmental concern.

No stage 5 in the DTM? I feel like that is very relevant to the end of the video. Stage 5 is a prediction, saying that death rates will stagnate whilst birth rates decrease due to lower child mortality rates, higher education levels, more access to contraception, female empowerment etc. This means that there will be a decrease in population, which is starting to occur in highly developed nations like Germany, Italy and Japan. This explains the global population's stability, because the growth rate of the many underdevelopment countries will be canceled out by the negative growth rates in MEDCs.

I mean, the slowing of population growth is excellent news, but some of the problems typically associated with overpopulation are still facing us because of sustainability. Namely, not everyone who currently lives can share the same standard of living as even the average American, because there aren't enough resources for it, and because of the predominant way we create energy, it would cause even more problems for our environment and accelerate climate change.

We STILL need to push for enhanced technologies for growing food both in greater amounts AND with safer practices, and we need to continually transition our energy creation from fossil fuels to renewables. And we need to make a stronger push for better and more public transportation, especially here in America, so that the car becomes far less required and our roads can be opened up significantly, while also enabling more and more people to get to more and more destinations, including places of employment and education.

This vid paints a rather rosy picture - it doesn't go into the other potential problem of  UNDERpopulation. If all countries go the same way (which looks likely) we'll have a worldwide shortage on our hands.

Normally I love these videos but I just can not agree with this one.

Yes better medicine did increase the population
Yes more people where having more children (total)

However the idea that people where not dying does not really play any roll in people having less children. In places like Japan where medicine is very good and living standards are very high show a declining population which in all honesty would support the argument of this video. I'm happy to admit that however places like China, the Middle East, and Central Asia are seeing a higher then average birth rate because of the urbanization.

People are more wealth so they can afford to have more children. On the other hand birth control has played a huge part in couples having less children. In the past there really wasn't many ways to prevent a unwanted birth you just had to deal with it. Not so today, you have the pill, condoms, and many other possibilities which where never touched on in this video.

Most of the developed world is seeing a lower standard of living. Jobs are not paying as much as they once where, competition has become far better (along the lines of automation, and cheap labor in developing countries), and the education requirements are rapidly increasing for jobs that pay less then they once have.

I could easily argue that the reason people are having less children is not because less are dying but because they simply can not afford the liability of having more children and the options available to prevent unwanted birth's have never been greater. You look at countries like China, Taiwan, Malaysia, and much of the Middle East have a different family model. It's expensive to have children there as well however in the long run it pays off to have many children as the family is much closer their and more hands working makes it cheaper for the family to survive. Teen's are expected to work in the rural fields and support the family as the older generation's watch over their children's and grand children's children.

That model supports itself while the model in the West is you raise them they then become independent and do not contribute a huge amount to the family afterwords which makes it much more expensive in those environments.

There is many reasons why people are having less children and no one answer is correct instead is a combination of many reasons that result in this out come. To say one reason is correct and only that reason is wrong.

I used to be really worried about overpopulation, but generally the arguments that are presented in this video consoled those fears in me. However, one huge oversight in this video is the potential for life-lengthening technologies. Predictions strongly indicate that people dying of non-age related reasons will keep continuing to decline, but right now those kinds of deaths are at an all-time low, which is why we can confidently say that dystopian overpopulation isn't an issue. However, this is only true because age-related deaths flat line the whole model. Once we start the process of exponentially lowering the death rate to age related diseases, I strongly expect that the population rate will continue to explode, and the solutions to that problem are... hairy, at best.

People of various religions have gone to their religious leaders and teachers to ask why there is so much suffering. Often, the response is that suffering is God’s will and that he long ago determined everything that would ever happen, including tragic events. Many are told that God’s ways are mysterious or that he brings death upon people—even children—so that he can have them in heaven with him. As you have learned, though, Jehovah God never causes what is bad. The Bible says: “It is unthinkable for the true God to act wickedly, for the Almighty to do wrong!”—Job 34:10.

Why do many people make the mistake of blaming God for the suffering in the world?

Do you know why people make the mistake of blaming God for all the suffering in the world? In many cases, they blame Almighty God because they think that he is the real ruler of this world. They do not know a simple but important truth that the Bible teaches. You learned that truth in Chapter 3 of this book. The real ruler of this world is Satan the Devil.

How does the world reflect the personality of its ruler? (b) How have human imperfection and “time and unexpected events” contributed to suffering?

The Bible clearly states: “The whole world is lying in the power of the wicked one.” (1 John 5:19) When you think about it, does that not make sense? This world reflects the personality of the invisible spirit creature who is “misleading the entire inhabited earth.” (Revelation 12:9) Satan is hateful, deceptive, and cruel. So the world, under his influence, is full of hatred, deceit, and cruelty. That is one reason why there is so much suffering.

A second reason why there is so much suffering is that, as discussed in Chapter 3, mankind has been imperfect and sinful ever since the rebellion in the garden of Eden. Sinful humans tend to struggle for dominance, and this results in wars, oppression, and suffering. (Ecclesiastes 4:1; 8:9) A third reason for suffering is “time and unexpected events.” (Read Ecclesiastes 9:11.) In a world without Jehovah as a protective Ruler, people may suffer because they happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.

Why can we be sure that Jehovah has a good reason for allowing suffering to continue?
It is comforting for us to know that God does not cause suffering. He is not responsible for the wars, the crimes, the oppression, or even the natural disasters that cause people to suffer. Still, we need to know, Why does Jehovah allow all this suffering? If he is the Almighty, he has the power to stop it. Why, then, does he hold back? The loving God that we have come to know must have a good reason.—1 John 4:8.

A VITAL ISSUE IS RAISED

What did Satan call into question, and how?

To find out why God allows suffering, we need to think back to the time when suffering began. When Satan led Adam and Eve into disobeying Jehovah, an important question was raised. Satan did not call into question Jehovah’s power. Even Satan knows that there is no limit to Jehovah’s power. Rather, Satan questioned Jehovah’s right to rule. By calling God a liar who withholds good from his subjects, Satan charged that Jehovah is a bad ruler. (Read Genesis 3:2-5.) Satan implied that mankind would be better off without God’s rulership. This was an attack on Jehovah’s sovereignty, his right to rule.

Why did Jehovah not just destroy the rebels in Eden?

Adam and Eve rebelled against Jehovah. In effect, they said: ‘We do not need Jehovah as our Ruler. We can decide for ourselves what is right and what is wrong.’ How could Jehovah settle that issue? How could he teach all intelligent creatures that the rebels were wrong and that his way truly is best? Someone might say that God should simply have destroyed the rebels and made a fresh start. But Jehovah had stated his purpose to fill the earth with the offspring of Adam and Eve, and he wanted them to live in an earthly paradise. (Genesis 1:28) Jehovah always fulfills his purposes. (Isaiah 55:10, 11) Besides that, getting rid of the rebels in Eden would not have answered the question that had been raised regarding Jehovah’s right to rule.

llustrate why Jehovah has allowed Satan to become the ruler of this world and why God has permitted humans to govern themselves.

Let us consider an illustration. Imagine that a teacher is telling his students how to solve a difficult problem. A clever but rebellious student claims that the teacher’s way of solving the problem is wrong. Implying that the teacher is not capable, this rebel insists that he knows a much better way to solve the problem. Some students think that he is right, and they also become rebellious. What should the teacher do? If he throws the rebels out of the class, what will be the effect on the other students? Will they not believe that their fellow student and those who joined him are right? All the other students in the class might lose respect for the teacher, thinking that he is afraid of being proved wrong. But suppose that the teacher allows the rebel to show the class how he would solve the problem.

A teacher allowing a rebel student to show the class a supposed solution to a difficult problem
Is the student more qualified than the teacher?

Jehovah has done something similar to what the teacher does. Remember that the rebels in Eden were not the only ones involved. Millions of angels were watching. (Job 38:7; Daniel 7:10) How Jehovah handled the rebellion would greatly affect all those angels and eventually all intelligent creation. So, what has Jehovah done? He has allowed Satan to show how he would rule mankind. God has also allowed humans to govern themselves under Satan’s guidance.

What benefit will come from Jehovah’s decision to allow humans to govern themselves?

The teacher in our illustration knows that the rebel and the students on his side are wrong. But he also knows that allowing them the opportunity to try to prove their point will benefit the whole class. When the rebels fail, all honest students will see that the teacher is the only one qualified to lead the class. They will understand why the teacher thereafter removes any rebels from the class. Similarly, Jehovah knows that all honesthearted humans and angels will benefit from seeing that Satan and his fellow rebels have failed and that humans cannot govern themselves. Like Jeremiah of old, they will learn this vital truth: “I well know, O Jehovah, that man’s way does not belong to him. It does not belong to man who is walking even to direct his step.”—Jeremiah 10:23.

WHY SO LONG?

Why has Jehovah allowed suffering to continue for so long? (b) Why has Jehovah not prevented such things as horrible crimes?

Why, though, has Jehovah allowed suffering to go on for so long? And why does he not prevent bad things from happening? Well, consider two things that the teacher in our illustration would not do. First, he would not stop the rebel student from presenting his case. Second, the teacher would not help the rebel to make his case. Similarly, consider two things that Jehovah has determined not to do. First, he has not stopped Satan and those who side with him from trying to prove that they are right. Allowing time to pass has thus been necessary. In the thousands of years of human history, mankind has been able to try every form of self-rule, or human government. Mankind has made some advances in science and other fields, but injustice, poverty, crime, and war have grown ever worse. Human rule has now been shown to be a failure.


Second, Jehovah has not helped Satan to rule this world. If God were to prevent horrible crimes, for instance, would he not, in effect, be supporting the case of the rebels? Would God not be making people think that perhaps humans can govern themselves without disastrous results? If Jehovah were to act in that way, he would become party to a lie. However, “it is impossible for God to lie.”—Hebrews 6:18.

What will Jehovah do about all the harm that has resulted from the rule of humans and the influence of Satan?

What, though, about all the harm that has been done during the long rebellion against God? We do well to remember that Jehovah is almighty. Therefore, he can and will undo the effects of mankind’s suffering. As we have already learned, the ruining of our planet will be undone by the turning of the earth into Paradise. The effects of sin will be removed through faith in Jesus’ ransom sacrifice, and the effects of death will be reversed by means of the resurrection. God will thus use Jesus “to break up the works of the Devil.” (1 John 3:8) Jehovah will bring all of this about at just the right time. We can be glad that he has not acted sooner, for his patience has given us the opportunity to learn the truth and to serve him. (Read 2 Peter 3:9, 10.) Meanwhile, God has been actively seeking sincere worshippers and helping them to endure any suffering that may come upon them in this troubled world.—John 4:23; 1 Corinthians 10:13.

Some might wonder, ‘Could all this suffering have been prevented if God had created Adam and Eve in such a way that they could not rebel?’ To answer that question, you need to remember a precious gift that Jehovah has given you.

This video doesn't address the real problem here, which is consumption of natural resources. As other countries develop, they want to live and eat like we do and use many more resources and it's simply impossible at this point for everyone in the world to do that. Consider that if everyone in the world lived like us Americans, we'd need 4 world's worth of natural resources (http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-33133712). So as population growth goes down in developing countries, their rates of consuming goes up and cancels it out. In essence, the population problem is not a developing world problem but a western problem, and videos like this only make it worse.

This is #$%&. Number of peeps depends only on how many kids they have on the average, since none dies nowadays before the age of 40. Assume peeps have 2.2 kids after they've reached the age of 20 and before they reach the age of 40. At the age of 40, their kids will start having kids too. Then parents die, and so every 20 years humanity grows by a factor 1.2. If there are N peepo today, then in n20 years there will be N 1.2^n peeps on the planet. So what happens in 100 years? Take n=5, in n20=5*20=100 years, there'll be N 1.2^5=N 2,5 peepo on Earth. So more than double. For as long as peeps have more than 2 kids on the average, there'll be a population explosion. Even 2.2 kids doubles us in less than 100 years. In 200 years? Take n=10, then 1,2^10=6,2. 300 years from now? 1.2^15=15,4. Have fun while you can :D Cheers :3
